title: Effectiveness of drag reduction device on simplified vehicle model: A CFD study
description: This thesis explores the effectiveness of a drag reduction device when applied to a simplified vehicle model. Using Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD), the study simulates how air flows around the vehicle, specifically looking at ways to reduce air resistance. It aims to understand if the chosen device can significantly lower drag, which would improve fuel efficiency and performance. Essentially, it's about using computer simulations to see if a particular design can make cars more aerodynamic. The research falls under the fields of aerodynamics and vehicle engineering, focusing on the practical application of fluid mechanics principles.

title: Design and analysis of a patient transfer system for enhanced mobility and safety
description: This thesis focuses on developing a new patient transfer system designed to make moving people safer and easier for both patients and caregivers. It will involve creating a detailed mechanical design, ensuring it's comfortable and user-friendly through ergonomic principles. The research will analyze how the system moves (kinematics) and its ability to withstand forces (solid mechanics) to guarantee stability and prevent injuries. Ultimately, the goal is to improve patient mobility while significantly reducing the risks associated with manual transfers, benefiting the healthcare industry.

title: Numerical Analysis of Bubble Dynamics in Bifurction vessels with stenosis and varying bifurcation angle
description: This thesis explores the complex behavior of bubbles as they navigate through blood vessels that split into two branches (bifurcation vessels). It specifically investigates how the presence of narrowing (stenosis) within these vessels, along with different angles at which the vessels split, affects the bubble's movement and shape. Using advanced computer simulations, the research aims to understand the fluid dynamics involved in such scenarios, which could have implications for medical applications like understanding gas embolisms or improving drug delivery. Essentially, it's about simulating how bubbles dance in diseased, branching arteries.

title: Biodiesel production optimization characterization of Mahogany seed oil response surface methodology
description: This thesis investigates the potential of Mahogany seed oil as a raw material for biodiesel production. It aims to find the best conditions (optimization) to convert this oil into biodiesel efficiently. The research will also thoroughly examine the properties (characterization) of the produced biodiesel to ensure it meets quality standards for use as a fuel. Response Surface Methodology will be employed as a statistical tool to design experiments and analyze how different factors influence the production process, ultimately leading to a more sustainable and renewable energy source.

title: Hematocrit Influence on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms through Fluid Structure Interaction
description: This thesis explores how variations in hematocrit, the concentration of red blood cells in blood, influence the progression and rupture risk of abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs). It will likely use advanced computational methods, specifically Fluid-Structure Interaction (FSI) models, to simulate the complex interplay between blood flow (fluid dynamics) and the aneurysm wall (structural mechanics). By altering hematocrit within these simulations, the research aims to understand how changes in blood viscosity and oxygen-carrying capacity affect wall stress, flow patterns, and overall aneurysm stability. This work falls under biomechanics and biomedical engineering, contributing to our understanding of AAA hemodynamics and potentially informing better diagnostic or treatment strategies for this dangerous cardiovascular condition.

title: Study the physical properties of furnace brick
description: This thesis aims to thoroughly investigate the various physical characteristics of furnace bricks, which are crucial components in high-temperature industrial applications. It will delve into understanding properties like their strength, durability, and resistance to extreme heat, exploring how these contribute to the brick's overall performance. The study will likely involve analyzing the material composition and microstructure of different brick types to explain their behavior under thermal stress. Key areas of focus could include assessing their thermal conductivity and heat capacity, crucial for efficient furnace operation and energy conservation. Ultimately, this research seeks to provide valuable insights into optimizing furnace brick design and material selection for improved industrial processes and longevity.

title: Mechanical properties evaluation of jute coconut fiber reinforced hybrid composite
description: This thesis likely investigates a new type of strong, lightweight material made from jute and coconut fibers. Researchers will be building and testing this "hybrid composite" to understand its mechanical properties, such as how strong it is, how it bends, and how it reacts to stress. The goal is to characterize the material and see if it can be used for various applications, potentially as a more sustainable alternative to traditional materials. This involves examining the unique characteristics and performance of these natural fibers when combined in a composite.

title: Design and fabrication of two stage impulse steam turbine
description: This thesis focuses on the complete process of creating a two-stage impulse steam turbine. It will involve the engineering design of the turbine components, considering principles of thermodynamics and fluid mechanics to ensure efficient energy conversion from steam. The project will also cover the practical aspects of fabricating these designed parts, bringing the theoretical model to a tangible, working prototype. Ultimately, the research aims to demonstrate the successful development and construction of such a turbomachinery system.

title: Study of 1-DoF Micromanipulator Based on Compound Amplification Mechanism
description: This thesis investigates the development of a small, precise robotic arm (micromanipulator) that moves in a single direction. The core idea is to achieve very fine control and movement by using a clever "compound amplification mechanism," which means combining several smaller movements to create a larger, highly accurate one. The research will likely focus on the mechanical design of this unique amplification system, aiming to make it precise, reliable, and compact. It will also probably involve aspects of robotics and mechatronics to understand how to best control this mechanism for delicate tasks, potentially even touching upon the control systems needed for its operation. Ultimately, this work aims to create a more effective micromanipulator for applications requiring extreme precision.

title: Design and fabrication of a one shell pass and two tube pass heat exchange
description: This thesis delves into the practical aspects of creating a specific type of heat exchanger. It likely focuses on the process of designing, modeling, and then physically building a "one shell pass and two tube pass" heat exchanger, which is a common configuration for efficient heat transfer. The research would involve calculating the necessary dimensions, selecting appropriate materials, and then detailing the step-by-step procedures for manufacturing and assembling the device. Ultimately, it aims to demonstrate the successful design and fabrication of such a system, potentially including testing its performance.

title: Effect of chemical treatment on water absorption characteristics of banana nanocellulose
description: This thesis explores how treating banana nanocellulose with different chemicals affects its ability to soak up water. Researchers will likely extract tiny fibers from banana plants, called nanocellulose, and then modify them using various chemical methods. The study will then carefully measure how much water these treated nanocellulose materials absorb compared to untreated ones. This research could help develop new, sustainable materials with controlled water absorption properties, potentially useful in things like packaging or composites. Ultimately, it seeks to understand if chemical treatments can make banana nanocellulose more or less water-resistant, opening doors for its use in diverse applications.

title: A numerical study of vibration and damping characteristics of coir and kenaf fiber reinforced composite materials
description: This thesis investigates how two natural fibers, coir (from coconuts) and kenaf, can be used to strengthen composite materials. The study focuses on understanding their vibration and damping characteristics, which are important for how materials behave when stressed or shaken. Instead of building physical prototypes, the research employs numerical analysis – essentially using computer simulations and mathematical models – to predict and analyze these properties. The goal is to determine how well these eco-friendly materials can absorb vibrations and reduce noise, potentially leading to their use in various engineering applications. Ultimately, this work aims to demonstrate the potential of sustainable, natural fiber composites as alternatives to traditional materials in situations where vibration control is crucial.

title: Characterization of Stir Casted Hybrid Al matrix Composite Reinforced with Al2O3 and TiO2
description: This thesis investigates a new type of lightweight, strong material called a hybrid aluminum matrix composite. The research focuses on making these composites by a method called "stir casting," where tiny particles of Al2O3 (alumina) and TiO2 (titanium dioxide) are mixed into molten aluminum. The main goal is to understand the properties of these new materials, such as their strength, hardness, and how they behave when subjected to stress. This characterization helps determine if these composites are suitable for various applications, potentially offering improved performance over traditional aluminum alloys. Essentially, it's about creating and testing better, more durable aluminum-based materials.

title: Design and motion control of a 360 Degree Mecanum wheel chair
description: This thesis explores the design and motion control of a unique wheelchair utilizing 360-degree Mecanum wheels. It will likely cover the mechanical aspects of building such a chair, including the frame, motor placement, and how these special wheels enable omnidirectional movement. A significant part will focus on the "motion control," which means developing the electronic brains and software to precisely steer and move the wheelchair in any direction, including sideways and rotating on the spot. The research will delve into the mathematical models (kinematics) describing how the wheels work together and how to translate user commands into smooth, accurate motion, potentially involving automated features for enhanced maneuverability and ease of use.

title: Comparative analysis of Al2O3, MgO, and SWCNT nanofluids for enhanced heat transfer in car radiators
description: This thesis explores the impact of using special "nanofluids" in car radiators to make them cool better. Instead of regular coolant, it investigates adding tiny particles of aluminum oxide (Al2O3), magnesium oxide (MgO), or even super-small carbon tubes (SWCNT) into the liquid. The main goal is to compare how well each of these different mixtures improves heat transfer, ultimately making the car's engine run cooler and more efficiently. It will likely involve experiments to measure how quickly heat moves through these modified coolants compared to standard ones, specifically within the context of a car's cooling system. This research could lead to more effective and compact radiator designs for vehicles.

title: Sustainable solid waste management at CUET, Raozan, Chittagong
description: This thesis likely investigates how to effectively manage solid waste generated at CUET, Raozan, Chittagong, in a way that benefits the environment and community long-term. It could explore current waste generation practices, identify key challenges, and propose sustainable solutions. The research might delve into methods like improved recycling programs, waste-to-energy initiatives, or composting to reduce pollution and promote resource recovery. Ultimately, it aims to develop practical strategies for CUET to handle its waste responsibly, contributing to a cleaner and more sustainable campus and local area.

title: Criticality Assessment of Power plant using fuzzy risk model
description: This thesis explores a new way to understand and improve the safety and reliability of power plants. It uses a "fuzzy risk model," a smart tool that helps account for the complexities and uncertainties in real-world power plant operations, much like how humans make decisions with incomplete information. By applying artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques, the research aims to identify the most critical components or events that could lead to problems, even small ones. This allows for better control systems and optimization strategies to prevent failures and enhance overall plant performance. Ultimately, the work involves simulating various scenarios to provide a more accurate and robust assessment of potential risks, leading to safer and more efficient energy production.

title: Waste water treatment using chicken eggshell as bio-flocculant
description: This thesis explores an innovative approach to cleaning wastewater by using an unexpected natural material: chicken eggshells. It investigates how finely crushed eggshells can act as a "bio-flocculant," a natural substance that helps small particles in dirty water clump together, making them easier to remove. The research aims to understand the eggshells' chemical and physical properties to optimize their effectiveness in pollution control. By repurposing a common waste product like eggshells, this study contributes to sustainable waste management and recycling efforts, offering a potentially eco-friendly and cost-effective solution for wastewater treatment.

title: Ergonomic Analysis of Patient Bed Cum Wheelchair for Immobilized Patients: Using Bangladeshi Anthropometric Data
description: This thesis explores the ergonomic design of a combined patient bed and wheelchair specifically for immobilized patients. It aims to analyze how well this device fits the physical characteristics of people in Bangladesh, ensuring comfort and ease of use. The research will likely involve studying the movements and postures of patients and caregivers to optimize the design for safety and efficiency. Using Bangladeshi anthropometric data, the thesis will seek to create a more user-friendly and practical solution that can improve patient care and reduce strain on caregivers. Ultimately, it hopes to contribute to better biomedical engineering designs tailored to local populations.

title: Regeneration of used engine oil using acid treatment by varying acid to oil ratio
description: This thesis investigates a method to recycle used engine oil, transforming it from a waste product back into a usable resource. The core idea is to use acid treatment to clean the oil, specifically by experimenting with different amounts of acid added to a set volume of oil. The research aims to find the optimal acid-to-oil ratio that effectively removes impurities and restores the oil's properties, thereby reducing environmental pollution and promoting sustainability. Ultimately, this work contributes to better waste management practices within the engine and automotive industry by offering a viable recycling solution.

title: Computational study of highway bus aerodynamics: use of backside airflow
description: This thesis proposes a computational study investigating how the airflow at the rear (backside) of highway buses can be harnessed to improve their aerodynamics. It will likely use advanced computer simulations (Computational Fluid Dynamics or CFD) to analyze how air moves around and behind these large vehicles. The core idea is to find innovative ways to manipulate or utilize this "backside airflow" to reduce drag, potentially leading to better fuel efficiency or stability. The research aims to explore novel aerodynamic designs or strategies focusing on the often-turbulent wake region behind buses. Essentially, it's about making buses more slippery through the air by cleverly managing the air they leave behind.

title: Criticality analysis of steel industry using fuzzy model
description: This thesis delves into understanding the most crucial aspects of the steel industry. It aims to identify potential bottlenecks or areas of failure that could significantly disrupt operations. By using a "fuzzy model," the research will account for the inherent uncertainties and subjective judgments often found in complex industrial systems. This Artificial Intelligence approach, likely involving Machine Learning, will help in accurately assessing risk and pinpointing where resources for improvement or Optimization should be focused within manufacturing processes. Ultimately, the goal is to enhance the steel industry's resilience and efficiency.

title: Spectroscopic analysis of household E-Waste and its management: ensuring environmental safety and exploring business opportunities
description: This thesis delves into household electronic waste (E-waste), focusing on its chemical makeup using spectroscopic techniques. It aims to understand what harmful substances might be present in common household E-waste, ensuring environmental safety. Beyond identifying pollutants, the research will also explore effective ways to manage this growing waste stream. Ultimately, it seeks to uncover potential business opportunities within E-waste recycling and management, turning a pollution challenge into a source of value while protecting our environment.

title: Design and fabrication of a hybrid CNC machine: combining subtractive and additive manufacturing technologies
description: This thesis will likely focus on creating a single machine that can both remove material (like cutting or milling) and add material layer by layer (like 3D printing). It will involve the engineering design and physical construction of this "hybrid" CNC (Computer Numerical Control) machine. The research will likely delve into the mechanical systems, electronic controls, and software necessary to seamlessly integrate these two distinct manufacturing processes into one device. The aim is to demonstrate the advantages and challenges of combining subtractive and additive manufacturing for greater versatility in creating parts. Essentially, it's about building a versatile factory-in-a-box for small-scale production or rapid prototyping.

title: Effect of nickel reinforcement on mechanical behavior of brass metal matrix composites
description: This thesis investigates how adding nickel to brass affects its strength and other mechanical properties. Researchers will create special composites, which are materials made from two or more different components, with brass as the main metal and nickel as a reinforcement. The study will likely involve testing these new materials to understand how they behave under stress, such as how much force they can withstand before breaking or deforming. This involves analyzing properties like hardness, tensile strength, and wear resistance. Ultimately, the goal is to understand if and how nickel improves the performance of brass for potential engineering applications.

title: Numerical Analysis of a Tube heat exchanger by inserting double counter twisted tape of different porosities
description: This thesis explores the heat transfer performance of a tube heat exchanger by incorporating a novel design element: double counter-twisted tapes. The research will numerically analyze how these tapes, with varying levels of porosity, affect the efficiency of heat exchange within the tube. By using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) techniques, the study aims to understand the intricate interplay between fluid flow and heat transfer. Specifically, it will investigate how different tape porosities influence the flow patterns, pressure drop, and ultimately, the rate at which heat is transferred. The findings could lead to improved designs for more efficient heat exchangers in various industrial applications.

title: Experimental investigation of heat transfer enhancement using hybrid nanofluid with insert helical coil in a double pipe heat exchanger
description: This thesis explores the impact of a novel cooling fluid and heat exchanger design on improving heat transfer efficiency. Specifically, it investigates using a "hybrid nanofluid," a liquid containing tiny particles of two different materials, as a more effective medium for carrying heat. This special fluid will be tested within a "double pipe heat exchanger," a common device for transferring heat between two fluids. To further enhance performance, a "helical coil" insert will be placed inside the heat exchanger, creating a swirling flow that could improve heat exchange. The research aims to experimentally determine how well this combination of hybrid nanofluid and helical coil design improves heat removal, potentially leading to more efficient cooling systems.

title: Study of flexural-based multi-stage asymmetric microgripper
description: This thesis focuses on designing and understanding a tiny, precision gripping tool called a microgripper. Specifically, it investigates a new type that uses flexible parts to open and close, has multiple stages for controlled movement, and is "asymmetric," meaning its design isn't perfectly balanced, possibly for specialized gripping tasks. The research likely involves the mechanical engineering principles behind how these tiny structures bend and deform (solid mechanics), alongside the practical challenges of actually building them at the microscale (fabrication) for applications in fields like nanotechnology or biological manipulation.

title: Numerical analysis of two phase ejector for enhanced fluid mixing
description: This thesis explores how a two-phase ejector can be optimized using numerical methods to improve fluid mixing. It will likely involve using computer simulations (Computational Fluid Dynamics) to understand the complex flow behavior when two different phases (like liquid and gas) interact within the ejector. The research aims to analyze the fluid mechanics involved, focusing on how the ejector design influences the mixing efficiency. Ultimately, this work seeks to enhance various industrial processes where effective fluid blending is crucial, potentially leading to more efficient designs for these devices.

title: Influence of fiber Orientation on the Mechanical Properties of Bamboo and Glass fiber Reinforced epoxy Composites
description: This thesis explores how the direction of fibers, specifically bamboo and glass fibers, affects the strength and other mechanical characteristics of epoxy-based composite materials. It investigates whether aligning these fibers in a particular way can make the resulting composite stronger, stiffer, or more resistant to damage. The research likely involves making different composite samples with varying fiber orientations and then testing them extensively to measure properties like tensile strength, flexural strength, and impact resistance. This work contributes to understanding how to design and create more effective and durable composite materials for various applications. It combines insights from natural fiber composites with traditional materials science, focusing on practical material characterization.

title: Design and fabrication of buoy type blue energy extraction system for enhanced efficiency and sustainability
description: This thesis explores the design and construction of a novel buoy-shaped system to harness energy from ocean waves. The core idea is to develop an efficient device that floats on the water and converts the movement of waves into usable electricity. It will investigate various mechanical designs and hydrodynamic principles to optimize how the buoy interacts with waves, aiming for maximum energy capture. A significant focus will be on the practical fabrication process, ensuring the system can be built effectively and affordably. Ultimately, the research seeks to create a sustainable and highly efficient solution for renewable energy generation from the vast resources of the ocean.

title: Optimization of de Laval nozzle at various divergent angles using computational fluid dynamics
description: This thesis explores how to make de Laval nozzles work as efficiently as possible by changing their shape. Using computer simulations, or "computational fluid dynamics," the research investigates how different "divergent angles" – the widening part of the nozzle – affect the flow of gas and the thrust produced. Essentially, it's about finding the best design for these specialized nozzles, which are crucial for things like rocket engines, to get the most power out of them. The study uses advanced computer modeling to test many designs without having to build and test them physically, aiming to "optimize" their performance for various applications.

title: Study the Physical Properties of Basic Steel Slag
description: This thesis aims to thoroughly investigate the fundamental physical characteristics of basic steel slag, a common byproduct of steel production. Researchers will likely employ various material characterization techniques to understand its density, porosity, and thermal behavior. A significant focus will be on evaluating its mechanical properties, such as strength and durability, to assess its potential for beneficial reuse. Ultimately, this study contributes to better waste management practices by exploring viable recycling opportunities for steel slag, transforming a waste product into a valuable resource for other industries.

title: Recycling of plastic waste into fuel: an alternative of fossil fuel
description: This thesis explores the innovative process of transforming plastic waste into usable fuel, offering a promising alternative to our reliance on fossil fuels. It investigates various methods of converting discarded plastics into energy, highlighting their efficiency and environmental benefits. The research likely assesses the economic viability and scalability of such recycling technologies, aiming to demonstrate their potential for widespread adoption. Ultimately, this work seeks to contribute to sustainable waste management practices and advance the development of renewable energy sources, paving the way for a more circular economy.

title: Numerical Analysis of natural Convection inside a Prismatic Enclosure with a Rectangular Heat Source
description: This thesis investigates how heat moves and fluids flow inside a prism-shaped container, specifically focusing on natural convection – the process where fluid movement is driven by temperature differences. Using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) and other numerical analysis techniques, the research simulates how a rectangular heat source within this enclosure affects the temperature distribution and fluid circulation patterns. Essentially, it's a computer-based study to understand and predict heat transfer behavior in a specific enclosed space without physically building it. The goal is to gain insights into how the shape of the enclosure and the heat source influence the overall heat transfer efficiency and fluid dynamics. This kind of simulation can be valuable for designing systems where heat management is crucial.

title: Heat transfer enhancement using Al2O3 nanofluid in a helical coil tube heat exchange
description: This thesis explores the impact of using a special liquid called Al2O3 nanofluid to improve how efficiently heat moves in a specific type of heat exchanger: a helical coil tube. It will likely investigate how adding tiny aluminum oxide (Al2O3) nanoparticles to a base fluid changes its heat transfer properties, aiming for better performance than traditional fluids. The research might involve experimental work or computational simulations to understand the fluid's flow behavior and its ability to transfer heat within the curved tube. The goal is to discover if this "nanofluid" can significantly enhance the heat exchange process, potentially leading to more compact and efficient heat exchanger designs for various applications. It combines principles from heat transfer, fluid mechanics, and material science, specifically focusing on the benefits of nanofluids.

title: Design a synthetic oleophilic mechanical skimmer for remediation of marine concern spill oils
description: This thesis focuses on developing a new type of oil spill cleanup device: a synthetic, oil-attracting mechanical skimmer. It will investigate how to design and build a robust, efficient skimmer that can effectively remove oil from the ocean surface. Key areas of research will include selecting the right materials that strongly attract oil but repel water, optimizing the skimmer's shape and moving parts for smooth operation in water (hydrodynamics), and exploring practical methods for manufacturing this device. Ultimately, the goal is to create an improved tool to help remediate marine oil spills and protect ocean environments.

title: Enhancement of solar PV panel performance using mirror reflection at different angle
description: This thesis explores the potential of using mirrors to enhance solar panel efficiency. It investigates how strategically placed mirrors, reflecting sunlight onto the panels from various angles, can increase the amount of solar energy captured. The research will likely focus on optimizing these mirror angles to maximize electricity generation, while also considering any potential side effects like increased heat on the panels. Ultimately, this study aims to find practical ways to make solar power more effective and affordable by harnessing additional sunlight.

title: Synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles and heat transfer analysis through helical coil tube in tube heat exchangers
description: This thesis likely focuses on two main areas: creating special tiny zinc oxide (ZnO) particles and then testing how well they improve heat transfer in a specific type of heat exchanger. The research would involve synthesizing these ZnO nanoparticles, which are incredibly small materials with unique properties. Subsequently, these nanoparticles would probably be dispersed in a fluid to create a "nanofluid" and then circulated through a "helical coil tube-in-tube heat exchanger." The core of the study would be analyzing how effectively this nanofluid transfers heat compared to conventional fluids within this particular heat exchanger design. Ultimately, the goal is to understand if using these ZnO nanoparticles can significantly enhance the heat transfer efficiency, potentially leading to more compact and efficient heat exchange systems.

title: Numerical study of the Thermal Management System of Commercial Li-ion Battery
description: This thesis focuses on using computer simulations to understand and improve how commercial lithium-ion batteries stay cool. It will likely investigate different cooling methods, often called Thermal Management Systems, to prevent batteries from overheating, which can degrade performance or even lead to safety issues. By applying principles of heat transfer and computational fluid dynamics (CFD), the research aims to model how heat moves within the battery and its cooling components. The goal is to design or optimize cooling systems for energy storage applications, ensuring these batteries operate efficiently and safely for longer durations. Essentially, it's about making better "air conditioning" for batteries using numerical tools.

title: Mechanical properties evaluation of banana-jute-pineapple fiber reinforced hybrid composite
description: This thesis investigates a new type of composite material made stronger by combining natural fibers from banana, jute, and pineapple plants. The research focuses on understanding how well this hybrid material performs mechanically, such as its strength and stiffness. It will likely involve making different versions of the composite and then testing them rigorously to see how they stand up to various stresses and strains. Ultimately, the goal is to evaluate if this eco-friendly material could be a viable alternative for various engineering applications.

title: Optimization of jackfruit seed oil biodiesel production using response surface methodology
description: This thesis aims to find the best way to make biodiesel from jackfruit seeds, a sustainable and renewable energy source. It will use a statistical technique called Response Surface Methodology (RSM) to understand how different factors like temperature or chemical amounts affect the biodiesel's quality and yield. The goal is to optimize the production process, making it more efficient and cost-effective. Ultimately, this research contributes to developing eco-friendly biofuels, promoting renewable energy, and enhancing sustainability in the energy sector by utilizing agricultural waste.

title: Design and fabrication of a SI engine
description: This thesis likely details the entire process of creating a Spark Ignition (SI) engine from concept to a working prototype. It would cover the mechanical design aspects, including component sizing and material selection, followed by the practical steps of manufacturing and assembling these parts. Key areas of study would involve the theoretical principles of internal combustion, particularly how fuel burns within the engine, and the challenges faced during the actual fabrication and testing phases. Essentially, it's about designing an engine on paper and then building it.

title: Fabrication and Characterization of aluminium metal matrix composites Reinforced MgO and Bamboo leaf Ash
description: This thesis investigates the creation and properties of new aluminum metal matrix composites. It focuses on reinforcing aluminum with two different materials: magnesium oxide (MgO), a common ceramic, and bamboo leaf ash, a natural and sustainable waste product. The research will likely involve fabricating these composites using various methods and then thoroughly examining their mechanical, physical, and possibly tribological characteristics. The goal is to understand how these specific reinforcements affect the aluminum's performance, potentially leading to materials with improved strength, hardness, or wear resistance for diverse applications.

title: Investigation of the mechanical characteristics of aluminum metal matrix composites reinforced with zinc and nickel
description: This thesis investigates aluminum composites, specifically focusing on how adding zinc and nickel affects their strength and behavior. It will explore how these additions change the mechanical characteristics of the aluminum, like its hardness, stiffness, and ability to withstand force. The research aims to understand the relationship between the composition of these metal matrix composites and their resulting mechanical properties. Essentially, it's about making aluminum stronger and more useful by mixing in other metals and then studying how those changes work.

title: Recycling of used engine oil through acid treatment
description: This thesis explores a promising method for transforming used engine oil, a significant environmental pollutant, into a valuable resource. It focuses specifically on the "acid treatment" process as a means to remove impurities and restore the oil's useful properties. The research aims to demonstrate how this recycling technique can reduce hazardous waste, mitigate soil and water contamination, and contribute to a more sustainable consumption of petroleum products. Ultimately, this work addresses critical issues in waste management and pollution control, offering a practical solution for minimizing the environmental footprint of the automotive industry.

title: Enhancing heat Transfer Rate by optimizing Fin shapes and Parameters using CFD Analysis
description: This thesis explores how to improve the efficiency of cooling systems, like those found in computers or engines, by making heat transfer more effective. It focuses on the tiny fins often used to dissipate heat, investigating how their shape and other characteristics influence their performance. Using computer simulations (Computational Fluid Dynamics or CFD), the research aims to find the best possible fin designs. The ultimate goal is to optimize these fin shapes and parameters to achieve a significantly enhanced heat transfer rate, leading to more efficient and effective heat exchangers and cooling solutions.

title: Cadmium Removal Using Egg and Peanut Shell
description: This thesis investigates the potential of common waste products, specifically egg and peanut shells, for removing hazardous cadmium from polluted water. It explores how these discarded materials, often landfilled, could act as low-cost, natural filters, offering an eco-friendly solution to heavy metal contamination. The research likely involves analyzing the shells' properties (Material Characterization) to understand their effectiveness, contributing to the fields of Pollution Control and Waste Management by proposing innovative Recycling strategies for agricultural byproducts. Ultimately, it aims to develop sustainable and accessible methods for environmental remediation.

title: Numerical analysis of Heat transfer enhancement of shell and Helical tube heat Exchanger
description: This thesis focuses on improving how effectively heat is transferred within a specific type of heat exchanger known as a shell and helical tube heat exchanger. Using numerical analysis, likely involving Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) simulations, the research aims to understand and quantify different methods of enhancing heat transfer within this system. The core of the work will involve creating computer models to simulate fluid flow and temperature distribution, allowing for the evaluation of various design modifications or operating conditions. Ultimately, the goal is to identify optimal strategies to make these heat exchangers more efficient at moving heat, which could have applications in many industrial processes.

title: Enhancing sedan car aerodynamics: Numerical and experimental analysis of rear diffuser angles for drag and lift reduction
description: This thesis explores how adding a rear diffuser to a sedan car can make it more aerodynamic. It will investigate different angles for this diffuser to see which one best reduces drag (the force slowing the car down) and lift (the force making the car feel lighter and less stable at speed). The research will use both computer simulations (numerical analysis, like CFD) and physical testing (experimental analysis) to understand these effects. The goal is to find the optimal diffuser design to make sedan cars more efficient and stable. This work is important for improving fuel economy and driving performance in everyday vehicles.

title: Synthesis of CuO Nanoparticles by chemical precipitation method and heat transfer analysis
description: This thesis investigates the creation of copper oxide (CuO) nanoparticles using a simple chemical precipitation method. It will detail the process of synthesizing these tiny materials and then thoroughly characterize them to understand their properties, such as size and structure. A significant part of the research will also focus on analyzing how these newly formed nanoparticles behave in terms of heat transfer. This involves studying how efficiently they can absorb, store, or transmit heat, which is crucial for potential applications. Ultimately, the work aims to connect the synthesis method and material characteristics to their thermal performance, contributing to both materials science and nanotechnology.

title: Analysis of Borassus flabellifer Fiber reinforced composite
description: This thesis is about creating and studying new composite materials. Specifically, it focuses on using fibers from the Borassus flabellifer tree (also known as the Palmyra palm) to strengthen these composites. The research will likely involve making different versions of these materials and then thoroughly testing their properties. This includes examining their structure and how strong and durable they are under various conditions, contributing to the field of natural fiber composites and sustainable material development.

title: Fabrication of nickel foam using the powder metallurgy method
description: This thesis focuses on creating nickel foam, a lightweight and porous material, using a technique called powder metallurgy. It will detail the specific steps involved in shaping nickel powder into a foam structure, including how different processing parameters might affect the final product. The research likely investigates the manufacturing process itself, aiming to optimize the method for producing high-quality nickel foam. Furthermore, the thesis will probably involve characterizing the fabricated foam's properties, such as its porosity, strength, and microstructure, to understand how well the chosen fabrication method performs. Ultimately, this work contributes to materials science by advancing our ability to produce complex materials like metal foams for various applications.

title: Numerical investigation of the flow through human trachea
description: This thesis explores how air moves through the human windpipe, or trachea, using computer simulations. Instead of observing actual breathing, the researcher will build virtual models of the trachea and use numerical methods to calculate how air flows and distributes within it. This work aims to understand how factors like the trachea's shape or obstructions might affect airflow, which is crucial for conditions like asthma or emphysema. Essentially, it applies principles of fluid mechanics and computational modeling to gain insights into a vital part of our respiratory system, contributing to both biomechanics and biomedical engineering.

title: Analysis of Hybrid composite using ABACA and areca Catechu natural fibers
description: This thesis investigates the creation and characteristics of a new type of composite material, often called a "hybrid composite." It specifically focuses on using two natural fibers, ABACA and areca catechu, which are plant-based and environmentally friendly alternatives to synthetic materials. The research will likely involve fabricating these composites, perhaps varying the proportions or arrangements of the fibers, and then rigorously testing their properties. The research would focus on understanding how strong it is, how it bends or breaks under different forces, and other important mechanical properties like stiffness or toughness. Essentially, the aim is to thoroughly "characterize" this hybrid composite, providing a complete picture of its mechanical performance through various tests and analyses. This understanding is crucial for determining if and where this material could be effectively used in real-world applications.

title: Mechanical Properties and Microstructure of a Dissimilar Resistance Spot Welded Joint of 201 Stainless Steel and Mild Steel
description: This thesis explores the mechanical properties and microstructure of a unique welded joint. Specifically, it focuses on resistance spot welds made between two different metals: 201 stainless steel and mild steel. The research likely investigates how strong these welds are (mechanical properties) and what their internal structure looks like (microstructure). It aims to understand how the welding process affects the joint's performance, considering the dissimilar nature of the materials. This involves examining features like grain structure, phase changes, and defects that influence the weld's strength and reliability. Ultimately, the thesis contributes to understanding and improving the manufacturing of components using these specific dissimilar material combinations.

title: Fabrication and Numerical Analysis of a VAWT for Variable Wind Speed Conditions
description: This thesis focuses on developing and testing a Vertical Axis Wind Turbine (VAWT). The research likely involves physically building a prototype of the VAWT ("Fabrication") and then using computer simulations ("Numerical Analysis" and "Computational Fluid Dynamics") to understand how it performs, especially when wind speeds change ("Variable Wind Speed Conditions"). The goal is to optimize its design and efficiency for generating electricity from the wind, contributing to "Wind Energy" and the broader field of "Renewable Energy." Essentially, it's about making a better, more adaptable wind turbine through both hands-on construction and advanced computer modeling.

title: Analysis of the Effect of Ethylene Glycol Concentration on Anodic Tin and Nickel Film
description: This thesis explores how varying the amount of ethylene glycol in a solution affects the formation of protective or functional films on tin and nickel surfaces using an electrochemical process called anodic deposition. It investigates whether different concentrations of this common chemical can lead to better quality coatings, potentially improving the materials' resistance to corrosion or enhancing their properties for other applications. Researchers would likely examine the structure, thickness, and performance of these films, aiming to understand the optimal conditions for creating durable and effective layers on these metals. The work combines principles of electrochemistry with materials science to develop new ways of modifying metal surfaces.

title: Characterization of Cadmium Impregnated Heavy Metal Removal by Sugarcane Bagasse
description: This thesis explores a sustainable way to remove toxic cadmium from water using sugarcane bagasse, a common agricultural waste product. It investigates how effectively this natural material can capture heavy metals, essentially cleaning polluted water. The research will also characterize the bagasse before and after treatment, understanding the chemical changes that allow it to absorb the cadmium. Ultimately, this work aims to develop an eco-friendly and cost-effective method for pollution control and waste management, turning an agricultural byproduct into a valuable resource for environmental remediation.

title: Performance Analysis of a Dual Diameter Closed-Loop Pulsating Heat Pipe for a Flat Plate Solar Collector with a Binary Fluid
description: This thesis investigates a novel cooling system for flat plate solar collectors, aiming to improve their efficiency. It focuses on a "pulsating heat pipe," a clever device that uses the boiling and condensation of a fluid to transfer heat. Uniquely, this heat pipe has two different diameters and employs a "binary fluid," meaning a mixture of two fluids, to potentially enhance its performance. The research will analyze how well this specific design works in terms of heat transfer, particularly when applied to a solar collector. Ultimately, it seeks to understand if this advanced heat pipe can effectively cool the solar collector, leading to more efficient renewable energy generation.

title: Effect of Post-Curing Heat Treatment on Mechanical Properties of Banana-Coir Hybrid Composite
description: This thesis explores how applying heat after a banana-coir hybrid composite is initially made (post-curing) affects its strength and behavior. It investigates whether this extra heat treatment can make the composite material, which combines banana and coconut fibers, more durable and perform better mechanically. The research will likely involve creating samples of this eco-friendly material and then subjecting some to specific heating processes. Afterward, various tests will be conducted to measure properties like tensile strength, flexural strength, and impact resistance. The goal is to understand if post-curing heat treatment is a viable method to enhance the mechanical properties of these natural fiber composites for potential applications.

title: Extraction of Fuel from Bicycle Scrap Tubes Through Pyrolysis Process
description: This thesis investigates the fascinating possibility of turning old bicycle inner tubes into valuable fuel. It focuses on a process called pyrolysis, which involves heating the rubber in the absence of oxygen to break it down. The goal is to extract liquid oil and gas from these discarded tubes, effectively recycling a common waste product. This research aims to demonstrate how we can generate biofuel from something typically thrown away, contributing to renewable energy sources and better waste management practices. Ultimately, it explores a sustainable method for converting scrap into a useful energy resource.

title: Detection of Defected Welds Using a Deep Learning Approach: A Method Based on a Convolutional Neural Network
description: This thesis explores a new way to find problems in welded parts using computer technology. Instead of humans inspecting every weld, which can be slow and error-prone, this research proposes training a "smart" computer program, specifically a Convolutional Neural Network (a type of deep learning), to automatically identify defects. It will likely involve feeding the computer many images of good and bad welds, allowing it to learn the subtle patterns that indicate a defect. The goal is to develop an efficient and accurate method for quality control in manufacturing, ultimately improving the safety and reliability of welded structures by quickly pinpointing flaws that might otherwise go unnoticed.

title: Detection of Knocking in SI Engine Using a Deep Learning Approach: A Method Based on Convolutional Neural Network
description: This thesis focuses on developing a smart system to detect "knocking" in gasoline engines, which is a harmful problem that can damage the engine. It proposes using a sophisticated computer program, a type of Artificial Intelligence called a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), to listen for and identify the unique vibrations caused by knocking. Essentially, the research aims to train a computer to recognize the subtle sounds or vibrations of engine knock, much like a doctor identifies a disease from symptoms. By applying advanced Machine Learning techniques to analyze engine vibration data, this work seeks to create a reliable and automated method for early knock detection, ultimately contributing to better engine performance and longevity.

title: Production Optimization and Characterization of Biodiesel from Tobacco Seed Oil
description: This thesis explores the potential of tobacco seed oil as a renewable source for biodiesel production. It likely investigates how to efficiently convert the oil into high-quality biodiesel through various optimization techniques, aiming to find the best process conditions. Furthermore, the research would involve thoroughly characterizing the produced biodiesel, analyzing its properties to ensure it meets fuel standards and performs well. Ultimately, this work contributes to developing sustainable biofuel alternatives and finding new uses for agricultural byproducts, advancing renewable energy solutions.

title: Analysis of the Effects of Variable Electrolyte Concentrations on the Surface Microstructure of an Anodic Al Film
description: This thesis explores how changing the amount of dissolved material (electrolytes) in a liquid affects the surface of an aluminum film created through an electrical process called anodization. Specifically, it investigates how these variable concentrations influence the tiny bumps, pits, and overall texture (microstructure) that form on the aluminum when it acts as the anode. The research likely uses various material characterization techniques to visualize and analyze these surface changes, aiming to understand the relationship between the electrolyte and the resulting film quality. This knowledge could be crucial for optimizing the fabrication of aluminum films with desired properties, potentially for applications in nanotechnology or to improve corrosion resistance.

title: Analysis of the Effects of Variable Electrolyte Concentrations on the Surface Microstructure of an Anodic Al Film
description: This thesis explores the impact of changing liquid chemical concentrations on the surface of an aluminum film created through an electrical process. Specifically, it investigates how varying the electrolyte solution used during anodization affects the tiny bumps, pits, and overall roughness of the resulting aluminum oxide layer. The research aims to understand how these concentration changes influence the material's properties at a nanoscale, which is crucial for applications like protective coatings or advanced materials. It delves into how different chemical environments during film growth can alter the final material's structure, potentially affecting its resistance to wear or its functionality in new technologies. This study combines aspects of material creation, surface analysis, and understanding how materials degrade or protect themselves.

title: Design and Fabrication of a Motorized Quick Lifting Mechanism Using Bevel Gear
description: This thesis focuses on the creation of a new, motorized lifting device designed for speed and efficiency. It will detail the process of designing the mechanism, with a particular emphasis on how a bevel gear system is integrated to facilitate quick lifting. The research will also cover the practical aspects of building the device, from selecting materials to the actual assembly and testing. Furthermore, it will likely delve into the movement principles (kinematics) of the lifting mechanism and explore its potential for automated operation in various applications. Ultimately, this work aims to demonstrate a functional and improved lifting solution through innovative mechanical design and careful fabrication.

title: Design and Fabrication of an Automatic Irrigation System for Multiple Fields
description: This thesis focuses on developing and building an automated irrigation system capable of watering several distinct agricultural fields without human intervention. It will involve designing the mechanical components necessary to distribute water efficiently, integrating various sensors to monitor soil moisture and environmental conditions, and creating a robust control system to intelligently manage watering schedules. The research will also encompass the practical fabrication of the system's hardware, combining elements of automation and control systems to optimize water usage and improve agricultural productivity across multiple areas.

title: Fabrication of a Laser Star Finder for Night Sky
description: This thesis likely focuses on the practical creation of a device designed to assist in locating stars in the night sky. It would involve the entire process of building such a "Laser Star Finder," from the initial conceptualization and detailed engineering drawings (Mechanical Design), to the actual construction and assembly (Manufacturing). A key aspect would be the integration and calibration of various sensing components (Sensors) that allow the device to accurately detect and point towards celestial objects using a laser. The research would culminate in demonstrating the fabrication process and the functionality of this new instrument for sky observation.

title: Co-Pyrolysis of Rice Husk and Low-Density Polyethylene
description: This thesis investigates the process of co-pyrolysis, a thermal conversion method, applied to two distinct waste materials: rice husk and low-density polyethylene (a common plastic). It aims to understand how combining and heating these materials in the absence of oxygen can transform them into valuable products, particularly focusing on the production of biofuel. The research likely explores the optimal conditions for this process, the types and quantities of liquids and gases produced, and the overall efficiency of converting these wastes into renewable energy. Ultimately, it contributes to sustainable waste management by recycling agricultural and plastic waste into a clean energy source.

title: CFD Analysis of a Plain Tube Heat Exchanger with Perforated & Rectangular Cut Twisted Tapes Using TiO2 Nanofluid
description: This thesis explores the heat transfer performance of a simple tube heat exchanger. It investigates how adding specially shaped inserts, called "twisted tapes" with both perforated and rectangular cuts, affects the efficiency. The study uses computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations to model the fluid flow and heat exchange. Instead of plain water, a nanofluid containing titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanoparticles is used as the working fluid to potentially enhance heat transfer. The ultimate goal is to understand how these modifications and the use of nanofluids can improve the design and operation of heat exchangers.

title: Design and Fabrication of a Thermoacoustic Refrigerator Using an Additively Manufactured Stack
description: This thesis focuses on developing a novel thermoacoustic refrigerator, a device that uses sound waves to create cooling, rather than traditional refrigerants. A key innovation will be the use of additive manufacturing (3D printing) to create the "stack," a crucial component that facilitates heat exchange and influences the refrigerator's efficiency. The research will delve into the design principles of thermoacoustic refrigeration, specifically optimizing the stack's geometry and material properties for enhanced heat transfer and acoustic performance. Furthermore, it will cover the practical fabrication process using additive manufacturing techniques and the subsequent experimental evaluation of the refrigerator's cooling capacity and efficiency. Ultimately, this work aims to demonstrate a more environmentally friendly and potentially more compact refrigeration technology by leveraging advanced manufacturing methods.

title: Fabrication of an Aluminum Matrix Composite Reinforced with Rice Husk Ash and Al2O3 Using Stir Casting Method
description: This thesis explores making a new, stronger material by mixing aluminum with two waste products: rice husk ash and alumina (Al2O3). The researchers will use a process called "stir casting," which is like stirring ingredients into molten metal, to combine these materials. The goal is to create a lightweight yet robust "metal matrix composite" that could have various engineering applications, potentially reducing waste and material costs. The study will likely investigate how adding these specific reinforcing particles affects the composite's strength, hardness, and other properties.

title: Production Optimization and Characterization of Biodiesel from Soapnut Seed Oil
description: This thesis focuses on making better biodiesel from an unusual source: soapnut seeds. Researchers will work on finding the best conditions (like temperature or catalyst amount) to convert soapnut seed oil into biodiesel efficiently. They will then thoroughly analyze the produced biodiesel to understand its properties and ensure it meets quality standards for use as fuel. The ultimate goal is to develop a more sustainable and efficient way to produce renewable energy from this novel feedstock.

title: Development of a Corrugated Roofing Sheet with a Sugarcane-Coir Fiber Hybrid Epoxy Composite
description: This thesis likely focuses on creating a new, eco-friendly roofing material. It will investigate using a blend of sugarcane bagasse and coir fibers, combined with epoxy resin, to form a composite that can be shaped into corrugated sheets. The research probably involves designing the composite material, developing a manufacturing process to make the sheets, and then testing their strength, durability, and other properties relevant for roofing applications. The aim is to produce a sustainable alternative to traditional roofing, potentially exploring its performance against standard materials and its potential for practical use.

title: Design and Fabrication of a Metacentric Apparatus
description: This thesis focuses on the complete process of creating a "metacentric apparatus." This device is designed and built to study the stability of floating bodies, a core concept in fluid mechanics and hydrodynamics. The research would likely cover the mechanical design aspects, including selecting materials and determining dimensions, followed by the actual fabrication and manufacturing of the physical apparatus. Ultimately, the aim is to produce a functional tool that can be used to experimentally demonstrate and analyze the metacentric height and its influence on a vessel's stability.

title: A Comparative Study of Catalyst Effects in Biodiesel Production and Its Blends Properties
description: This thesis explores the impact of different catalysts on the process of making biodiesel. It investigates how various catalysts influence the efficiency and speed of the chemical reactions involved in converting vegetable oils or animal fats into biodiesel. Furthermore, the study will analyze the final properties of the produced biodiesel and its blends, looking at factors like how well it flows, how cleanly it burns, and its stability. The goal is to understand which catalysts perform best and how they affect the quality and performance of this renewable fuel. This research contributes to developing more efficient and effective methods for biodiesel production, supporting the transition to sustainable energy.

title: Study of Welding Properties at the Welded Portion: Arc and Gas Welding
description: This thesis will investigate the characteristics of welds created using two common techniques: arc welding and gas welding. It aims to understand how these different methods affect the material at the point where pieces are joined. Specifically, the study will focus on analyzing various properties of the welded area, such as its strength, hardness, and how it behaves under stress. By comparing the results from arc and gas welding, the research will shed light on which method produces more desirable mechanical properties in the finished weld. This will involve material characterization techniques to evaluate the microstructure and overall quality of the welded joint. Ultimately, the findings could help engineers and fabricators choose the best welding process for specific applications, ensuring strong and reliable connections.

title: Numerical Investigation of Heat Transfer Enhancement Through a Tube Fitted with Perforated Hexagonal and Conical Rings
description: This thesis explores how to make heat transfer more efficient within a tube by adding special rings inside. Researchers are using computer simulations (Computational Fluid Dynamics) to understand how different shapes – specifically perforated hexagonal and conical rings – affect the flow of fluid and how well heat moves from one place to another. The study aims to numerically investigate if these internal modifications can significantly enhance heat transfer, which is crucial for improving the performance of heat exchangers and other thermal systems. Essentially, it's about finding the best ring design to make things heat up or cool down faster and more effectively.

title: A Study on the Effects of Homogeneous (KOH) and Heterogeneous (CaO) Catalysts on the Characteristics of Peanut Oil Biodiesel and Blends
description: This thesis investigates how different catalysts, specifically the liquid KOH (homogeneous) and solid CaO (heterogeneous), influence the quality and properties of biodiesel made from peanut oil. It aims to understand if using these catalysts, either alone or in combination, affects the fuel's characteristics, like its viscosity, density, or combustion efficiency. The research will also explore how blending this peanut oil biodiesel with conventional diesel impacts the overall fuel performance. Ultimately, this study contributes to finding more efficient and sustainable ways to produce renewable energy from biomass, potentially leading to better biofuel options.

title: Design and Fabrication of a Single-Pass Shell and Tube Heat Exchanger
description: This thesis delves into the complete process of creating a single-pass shell and tube heat exchanger. It likely covers the initial mechanical design considerations, including material selection and geometric configuration, to ensure efficient heat transfer. The study would then detail the various fabrication techniques employed to construct the device, addressing practical manufacturing challenges and quality control. Furthermore, it might analyze the theoretical principles of heat transfer that govern the exchanger's performance, potentially including experimental validation. Ultimately, this work combines engineering design, hands-on fabrication, and heat transfer analysis to demonstrate the successful production of a functional heat exchange unit.

title: Computational Study on the Aerodynamic Performance of a Modified Darrieus Wind Turbine
description: This thesis investigates how changes to a Darrieus wind turbine's design affect its efficiency in converting wind into power. Using computer simulations, the study aims to understand the complex flow of air around the modified turbine blades, which falls under the field of computational fluid dynamics. The goal is to identify design improvements that could make Darrieus turbines more effective and reliable sources of renewable energy. Ultimately, this research contributes to the advancement of sustainable wind energy technologies by optimizing turbine performance.

title: Fabrication and Analysis of an Al-Sn Metal Matrix Composite by Stir Casting Technique
description: This thesis explores the fabrication of an Aluminum-Tin (Al-Sn) metal matrix composite using the stir casting technique. It will likely detail the process of mixing tin particles into a molten aluminum matrix, aiming to create a new material with enhanced properties. The research will then focus on analyzing the fabricated composite, investigating its microstructure, mechanical strength, and other relevant material characteristics. Ultimately, the thesis seeks to understand how the stir casting method influences the Al-Sn composite's properties and its potential applications.

title: Pyrolysis of Polypropylene Using an Infrared Heat Source and Characterization of the Pyro-Oil
description: This thesis investigates a method for recycling polypropylene plastic waste. It focuses on breaking down the plastic using an infrared heat source, a process called pyrolysis, to transform it into a useful liquid product called pyro-oil. The research will likely involve designing and running experiments to find the best conditions for this conversion. A key part of the study will also be thoroughly analyzing the chemical and physical properties of the resulting pyro-oil to understand its potential applications, possibly as a fuel or chemical feedstock. Ultimately, this work contributes to waste management strategies and the development of new ways to create valuable materials from plastic waste.

title: Design and Analysis of a Three-Stage Compliant Asymmetric Microgripper
description: This thesis focuses on the creation and evaluation of a specialized, miniature gripping device. It likely delves into the mechanical design of a three-stage microgripper that is compliant, meaning it achieves movement through material deformation rather than traditional hinges, and asymmetric in its structure. The research probably involves extensive use of finite element analysis to simulate its behavior, understand stress distribution, and analyze its performance under various conditions, all rooted in principles of solid mechanics. The goal is to design a high-precision micromanipulator capable of handling delicate objects at a very small scale.

title: Fabrication and Analysis of the Mechanical and Chemical Properties of a Metal Matrix Composed of Zinc-Tin
description: This thesis delves into creating and understanding a new metal alloy. Specifically, it focuses on fabricating a metal matrix composite using a blend of zinc and tin. The research will involve carefully preparing this material and then thoroughly testing its physical strength and how it reacts chemically. By analyzing these mechanical and chemical properties, the study aims to understand how the zinc-tin combination performs, potentially revealing its suitability for various applications. It's essentially about making a new material and figuring out what it's good for.

title: Production of Biogas from Cow and Chicken Manure
description: This thesis investigates the process of converting cow and chicken manure into biogas, a valuable renewable energy source. It will likely explore the different methods and optimal conditions for anaerobic digestion, the biological process that breaks down organic waste to produce methane-rich biogas. The research aims to understand how to efficiently generate clean energy from agricultural waste, thereby addressing both waste management challenges and the demand for sustainable energy. By converting animal waste into biofuel, this study contributes to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and promoting circular economy principles. Ultimately, it seeks to demonstrate the potential of manure as a viable and sustainable feedstock for energy production.

title: Mechanical Properties Characterization of Stir Casted Hybrid Aluminum Metal Matrix Composite Reinforced with Nano Titanium Dioxide
description: This thesis explores the creation and mechanical properties of a new type of strong, lightweight material. It focuses on making an aluminum composite material by a method called "stir casting," where nano titanium dioxide particles are mixed into molten aluminum. The research aims to understand how adding these tiny particles affects the material's strength, hardness, and ductility. Essentially, it investigates if these nano-reinforcements can make aluminum much stronger and more durable for various applications. This involves testing the new material to characterize its behavior under different stresses.

title: Ionizing Radiation Shielding Analysis and Mechanical Properties Evaluation of Some Tin-Based Metal Alloys
description: This thesis explores the potential of certain tin-based metal alloys for use as shielding against ionizing radiation. It will likely investigate how effective these specific alloys are at blocking harmful radiation. Beyond that, the research will also evaluate the mechanical properties of these materials, such as their strength, hardness, and ductility. Understanding these properties is crucial to determine if the alloys are not only good at shielding but also durable and practical for real-world applications. The study aims to find materials that offer a good balance between radiation protection and robust physical characteristics.

title: Evaluation of the Corrosion Resistance of Anodized Aluminum Using Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy
description: This thesis explores how well a special coating, called anodization, protects aluminum from rusting or degrading. It uses a clever electrical test called Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) to measure this protection. By applying small electrical signals and seeing how the material responds, the research can figure out how resistant the anodized layer is to corrosion over time. This helps determine the effectiveness of anodized aluminum in various applications and contributes to understanding better ways to protect this common metal. Essentially, it's about checking the "rust-proof" quality of specially treated aluminum using an advanced electrical "X-ray" for materials.

title: Experimental Investigation of the Internal Resistance of Commercial Acid Batteries
description: This thesis explores the internal resistance of common acid batteries, like those found in cars. It aims to understand how this resistance affects their performance and efficiency, especially in storing energy. The research will likely involve various experimental techniques to measure and characterize this internal resistance under different conditions. By doing so, it contributes to materials science by shedding light on the electrochemical properties of battery components. Ultimately, the findings could help in developing more efficient and durable energy storage solutions.

title: Design and Fabrication of a Mini Thermoelectric Refrigerator
description: This thesis focuses on the creation of a small-scale refrigerator that operates using thermoelectric principles, rather than traditional compressor-based cooling. It will likely detail the design process, including selecting appropriate thermoelectric modules and optimizing their placement for efficient heat removal. The fabrication aspect will cover the physical construction of the device, from the casing to integrating the electrical components. Furthermore, the research will involve analyzing the heat transfer mechanisms within the refrigerator to understand its cooling performance and identify areas for improvement. Ultimately, it aims to demonstrate a functional and compact cooling solution.

title: Fabrication of Roofing Sheets with Epoxy Banana Fiber Composite
description: This thesis investigates the creation of new roofing sheets using a unique material: epoxy banana fiber composite. It will likely detail the process of fabricating these sheets, focusing on how the natural banana fibers are combined with epoxy resin to form a strong composite material. The research will also involve extensive material characterization to understand the properties of the fabricated sheets, such as their strength, durability, and water resistance, to determine their suitability as a roofing material. Ultimately, this work aims to develop an innovative and potentially more sustainable manufacturing method for roofing, utilizing natural fibers in composite applications.

title: Fabrication of Roofing Sheets with Epoxy Banana Fiber Composite
description: This thesis likely investigates the creation of new, more sustainable roofing sheets. It focuses on using banana fibers, a natural waste product, as a reinforcement material within an epoxy resin matrix to form a composite. The research would involve the actual "fabrication" process, detailing how these sheets are made, and then likely evaluating their properties like strength and durability. The ultimate goal is to develop an environmentally friendly and potentially cost-effective alternative to traditional roofing materials, contributing to advancements in "Natural Fiber Composites" and "Materials Science."

title: Fabrication and Characterization of Ni Foam by Powder Metallurgy Technique
description: This thesis likely focuses on creating nickel (Ni) foam, a porous metal structure, using the powder metallurgy method. The research would involve detailed steps for fabricating the foam, possibly exploring how different parameters like powder size or processing temperature affect the final product. A significant portion of the work would then be dedicated to characterizing the fabricated Ni foam, meaning analyzing its properties like pore size, strength, and electrical conductivity. The ultimate goal is to understand the relationship between the fabrication process, the resulting structure, and the properties of the Ni foam, potentially for applications requiring lightweight, high-surface-area materials.

title: Design and Fabrication of a Solar Scarecrow: An Approach to Solve the Rural Agriculture Problem in Bangladesh Using Modern Day Technology
description: This thesis focuses on developing a "Solar Scarecrow" to address agricultural challenges in rural Bangladesh. It involves the design and fabrication of a device that uses solar energy to autonomously deter pests, aiming to protect crops and improve yields. The research will delve into the mechanical design of the scarecrow, integrating renewable energy solutions for sustainable operation. Ultimately, it seeks to demonstrate how modern technology, specifically automation and solar power, can provide an effective and accessible solution for farmers facing crop damage.

title: Numerical Analysis of Low-Velocity Impact on Jute/Epoxy Composite Plate
description: This thesis will use computer simulations to study what happens when something gently bumps into a plate made from jute (a natural fiber) and epoxy (a type of plastic). It will specifically look at how the plate deforms and absorbs energy during these low-velocity impacts. The research will employ numerical methods, likely Finite Element Analysis, to model the composite material and understand its mechanical behavior. The goal is to predict how these eco-friendly composite plates respond to real-world impacts, contributing to the design of safer and more sustainable materials.

title: A Comparative Numerical Study on the High-Velocity Impact Performance of Fiber-Reinforced Polymer Composites
description: This thesis explores the high-velocity impact performance of fiber-reinforced polymer composites. It will use computer simulations, specifically numerical and finite element analysis, to compare how different composite materials react when hit very fast. The study aims to understand their mechanical properties under these extreme conditions, simulating real-world scenarios like aerospace or ballistic impacts. Essentially, it's about predicting how these strong, lightweight materials behave when struck at high speeds, all through advanced computer modeling rather than physical testing.

title: Multi-Staged Tesla Valve: A Study on Its Effect for Instability Reduction in Natural Circulation Loops
description: This thesis investigates the potential of a multi-staged Tesla valve to enhance stability in natural circulation loops. Specifically, it aims to understand how this unique valve design can reduce undesirable flow instabilities, which are crucial for the efficient operation of various cooling systems. Using computational fluid dynamics, the research will model and analyze the complex fluid mechanics and heat transfer phenomena within these loops. The study will likely focus on single-phase or multiphase flow behavior and the valve's ability to dampen pulsations and improve overall system reliability. This work could significantly contribute to the design of more stable and effective cooling technologies.

title: Thermal Performance Analysis of a Helical Coil and Shell Heat Exchanger by Polysaccharides
description: This thesis investigates how well a specific type of heat exchanger, a helical coil and shell design, transfers heat. The unique aspect is the use of polysaccharides (complex carbohydrates, essentially natural polymers) as the working fluid, instead of traditional liquids like water or oil. The research will likely involve analyzing how the shape of the coil affects heat transfer and fluid flow. It probably utilizes computational fluid dynamics (CFD) to simulate and predict the thermal performance, potentially aiming to optimize the design or understand the peculiar behavior of these natural fluids in heat exchange applications. The study aims to understand the "thermal performance" – how efficiently it heats or cools – when these natural, potentially eco-friendly substances are involved.

title: Design and Fabrication of Horizontal High-Energy Ball Milling Machine
