description: This thesis focuses on the complete process of creating a horizontal high-energy ball milling machine. It will likely cover the conceptualization and engineering of the machine's components, ensuring it can effectively pulverize materials to a fine powder. The research will delve into the practical aspects of building the machine, including material selection, machining processes, and assembly techniques. Ultimately, the thesis aims to demonstrate a functional machine capable of producing advanced powders, potentially for applications in materials science and powder metallurgy.

title: Computational Study on the Aerodynamic Behavior of the Ahmed Body Model with an Underbody Diffuser
description: This thesis explores the aerodynamic behavior of the Ahmed body, a simplified car model, through computational methods. Specifically, it investigates how adding an underbody diffuser, a common automotive component, affects airflow and forces like drag and lift. Using computer simulations (Computational Fluid Dynamics), the research aims to understand how this modification can improve vehicle performance and fuel efficiency. It will likely analyze pressure distributions, flow separation, and wake structures around the body. Essentially, it's about using virtual experiments to design more aerodynamically efficient cars.

title: Design and Fabrication of a Heat Pipe Using Refrigerant R-600a as a Working Fluid
description: This thesis likely focuses on creating and testing a heat pipe, a device that efficiently transfers heat from one point to another. The unique aspect here is using R-600a, a refrigerant often found in refrigerators, as the fluid inside the heat pipe. The research would involve designing the physical structure of the heat pipe, carefully fabricating it in a lab, and then conducting experiments to see how well it cools or moves heat. This work touches upon fundamental heat transfer principles, mechanical design considerations for building such a device, and its potential application as an effective cooling component in various systems.

title: A Study on the Use of Electrochemical Impedance of a Commercial Lithium-Ion Battery
description: This thesis investigates how a technique called Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) can be used to understand the internal workings and health of everyday lithium-ion batteries. It aims to characterize how the battery's components, like the electrodes and electrolyte, behave over time and under different conditions. By analyzing the "impedance" or resistance to alternating current, the research can reveal insights into processes such as material degradation, charge transfer efficiency, and even signs of internal "corrosion" that affect battery performance and lifespan. Ultimately, this study seeks to provide a non-destructive way to assess the state of commercial batteries, contributing to better battery design, usage, and longevity in energy storage applications.

title: A Study on the Use of Electrochemical Impedance of a Commercial Lithium-Ion Battery
description: This thesis investigates how a common, store-bought lithium-ion battery behaves by using a clever technique called Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS). It's like giving the battery a small electrical "ping" and listening to its "echo" to understand its internal health and how well it's storing energy. The study aims to characterize the battery's components and processes, looking for insights into how it ages or degrades over time. This research is important for improving battery performance, extending their lifespan, and understanding potential issues like internal resistance or even early signs of corrosion within the battery. Ultimately, it contributes to better energy storage solutions.

title: A Study on the Use of Electrochemical Impedance of a Commercial Lithium-Ion Battery
description: This thesis delves into understanding how a common lithium-ion battery works by using a special technique called Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS). It's like giving the battery a "check-up" to see its internal health and how well it stores and releases energy. The study will likely focus on characterizing the materials inside the battery and how they behave over time, which is crucial for improving battery performance and lifespan. By analyzing the "impedance" – essentially the battery's resistance to electrical flow at different frequencies – the researcher can pinpoint issues like degradation or even early signs of "corrosion" within the battery components, contributing to better battery design and management in energy storage systems.

title: A Study on the Use of Electrochemical Impedance of a Commercial Lithium-Ion Battery
description: This thesis likely investigates how "electrochemical impedance" – a powerful technique – can reveal the inner workings and health of everyday lithium-ion batteries. It aims to understand how components within these batteries behave electrically, possibly identifying issues like degradation or inefficiencies over time. Researchers might use this method to characterize battery materials, study internal "corrosion" or aging processes, and ultimately find ways to "optimize" battery performance and longevity. The study contributes to "energy storage" advancements by improving our understanding of these critical power sources.

title: CFD Analysis of Dimple Effects on a Horizontal Axis Wind Turbine Blade
description: This thesis investigates how small, indentations, or "dimples," on the surface of a horizontal axis wind turbine blade affect its performance. Using computational fluid dynamics (CFD), the research simulates airflow around these modified blades to understand how the dimples might alter aerodynamic forces like lift and drag. The goal is to determine if these surface features can improve the turbine's efficiency, allowing it to capture more wind energy. Ultimately, this work contributes to the field of renewable energy by exploring novel ways to optimize wind turbine blade design for better power generation.

title: A Modified Design of a Leaf Spring Suspension System with an Installation of a Simple Coil Spring
description: This thesis aims to improve the performance of traditional leaf spring suspension systems, commonly found in vehicles, by integrating a simple coil spring. It will likely involve designing a new configuration for the leaf spring that accommodates this additional coil spring. The research will focus on analyzing the stress distribution and overall solid mechanics of this modified system to ensure its strength and durability. Ultimately, the goal is to optimize the suspension's characteristics, potentially enhancing ride comfort, load-carrying capacity, or both, through this innovative mechanical design.

title: Design and Fabrication of a Solar-Powered Gamma-Type Stirling Engine using a Point-Focus Parabolic Solar Collector
description: This thesis aims to develop and build a unique solar-powered engine. Specifically, it focuses on designing and fabricating a "Gamma-Type Stirling Engine," which is a special kind of heat engine. The engine will be powered by sunlight concentrated using a "point-focus parabolic solar collector," effectively harnessing solar energy. The research will involve the practical construction and testing of this engine, investigating how well it converts solar heat into mechanical power. It will delve into the thermodynamics behind its operation, seeking to optimize its efficiency for renewable energy generation. Ultimately, the goal is to demonstrate a tangible and functional solar-powered engine prototype.

title: Heat Transfer Enhancement by Using Annular Fin
description: This thesis explores the impact of adding special ring-shaped "fins" to surfaces to improve how well heat moves from one place to another. It will likely investigate how different sizes or arrangements of these annular fins can make heat transfer more efficient, particularly within systems like heat exchangers. The research might involve analyzing fluid flow around these fins and using optimization techniques to find the best design for maximum cooling or heating performance. Ultimately, it aims to develop better methods for managing temperature in various engineering applications.

title: Numerical Investigation of a Fixed Wing Mini UAV
description: This thesis likely focuses on understanding how a small, fixed-wing unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) performs using computer-based methods rather than physical experiments. It will probably involve creating detailed virtual models to simulate the airflow around the UAV (Computational Fluid Dynamics) and predict its aerodynamic characteristics like lift and drag. The research might then use these predictions to analyze the UAV's flight stability, maneuverability, and potentially design or optimize its control systems to ensure smooth and accurate flight. Ultimately, it aims to gain insights into the UAV's behavior in various conditions through numerical simulations, saving time and resources compared to real-world testing.

title: Fabrication and Mechanical Characterization of Alkaline-Treated Natural Fiber Reinforced Hybrid Composite
description: This thesis explores the creation and testing of new materials called "hybrid composites." These composites are strengthened by natural fibers, which have been pre-treated with an alkaline solution to improve their performance. The research will involve fabricating these materials, meaning making them in the lab, and then thoroughly characterizing them. A key focus will be understanding their mechanical properties, such as how strong or stiff they are under different forces. Ultimately, this work aims to develop environmentally friendly natural fiber composites with enhanced characteristics for various applications.

title: Development of a Gravity-Powered Light Gear Transmission
description: This thesis investigates the design and development of a novel mechanical transmission system that harnesses gravitational potential energy to power a light gear mechanism. It focuses on the mechanical design aspects, exploring various kinematic configurations to efficiently convert falling weights into rotational motion. A key element will be optimizing energy storage and transfer within the system to ensure continuous and reliable operation, potentially offering a sustainable and renewable energy solution for low-power applications. The research aims to develop an efficient and practical gravity-powered device, analyzing its performance and potential for real-world implementation.

title: Experimental Study of Thermal Performance of a Combined Horizontal/Vertical/Lateral Perforated Elliptical Pin Fin Heat Sink with a Dimpled Base Plate
description: This thesis explores the thermal performance of a uniquely designed heat sink, which is a device used to cool electronic components. The heat sink features a combined horizontal, vertical, and lateral arrangement of perforated elliptical "pin fins" – small protrusions designed to maximize heat dissipation. It also incorporates a dimpled base plate, a surface with small indentations, likely to further enhance heat transfer. The study will involve experiments to understand how effectively this specific heat sink design transfers heat away, investigating factors like temperature distribution and overall cooling efficiency. The research aims to improve cooling systems, potentially leading to more efficient and reliable electronic devices. Ultimately, it contributes to the fields of heat transfer and fluid mechanics by examining an innovative heat sink geometry.

title: Performance Analysis of a Finned Single Basin Solar Still Integrated with a PCM-Based Heat Sink
description: This thesis investigates ways to make solar stills more efficient at producing clean water. It focuses on a specific type called a 'finned single basin solar still,' which uses fins to enhance heat transfer. The core idea is to integrate a Phase Change Material (PCM) based heat sink, which stores excess solar energy as latent heat when available, and then releases it later to maintain water evaporation. This helps the still operate more consistently, even after the sun sets. Ultimately, the research aims to improve the overall performance and productivity of these solar stills for sustainable water purification.

title: Analysis of Anti-Lock Braking System in Simulink
description: This thesis focuses on understanding how an Anti-lock Braking System (ABS) works by building and testing a virtual model of it. Using Simulink, a powerful simulation tool, the research will analyze how ABS controls wheel slip during braking to prevent skidding and improve vehicle stability. It will likely involve designing the control logic for the ABS, simulating different driving scenarios, and evaluating its performance, offering insights valuable for vehicle engineering and mechatronics. The study aims to demonstrate how numerical analysis can be applied to develop and optimize such critical control systems.

title: Enhancement of Specific Heat Capacity of Binary Carbonate Salt Using CuO and ZnO Nanoparticles
description: This thesis explores the impact of adding tiny copper oxide (CuO) and zinc oxide (ZnO) particles to a common energy storage material: a binary carbonate salt. The main goal is to improve how well this salt can store heat, specifically by increasing its "specific heat capacity." This means the salt could absorb and release more heat energy for applications like concentrated solar power or industrial waste heat recovery. Researchers will likely characterize the enhanced salt mixture to understand its new thermal properties and how the nanoparticles improve its performance. Ultimately, this work aims to develop a more efficient and effective material for thermal energy storage, contributing to cleaner and more sustainable energy solutions.

title: Convection Heat Transfer and Exergy Loss Investigation of a Helical Coil and Shell Heat Exchanger and Drag Reduction by Guar Gum
description: This thesis explores the efficiency and energy loss in a specific type of heat exchanger: a helical coil and shell design. It focuses on how heat is transferred by convection and how much useful energy (exergy) is wasted during this process. The research also investigates how a common substance, guar gum, can be added to the fluid to reduce drag, which in turn could lead to better performance. Ultimately, it aims to understand and potentially improve the heat transfer capabilities and energy efficiency of this heat exchanger using both experimental and computational methods.

title: Design and Fabrication of a Coal Pulverizer
description: This thesis focuses on the complete process of creating a coal pulverizer, a machine essential for preparing coal for combustion. It likely covers the initial design phase, including selecting materials and determining optimal component dimensions using principles of mechanical design and solid mechanics to ensure durability and efficiency. The work will then delve into the practical aspects of fabricating and manufacturing the pulverizer, detailing the construction methods and challenges faced. Furthermore, the thesis might explore ways to optimize the pulverizer's performance, perhaps through design modifications or operational adjustments, aiming for increased efficiency and reduced wear. Ultimately, it's a comprehensive study from concept to creation of a critical industrial machine.

title: Experimental Study for Thermal Performance and Pressure Loss Characteristic of Water Mixed with Al2O3 Nano Fluid in a Car Radiator
description: This thesis explores how mixing tiny aluminum oxide (Al2O3) particles into water, creating a "nanofluid," affects the performance of a car radiator. The study focuses on two main aspects: how well this new fluid transfers heat (thermal performance) and how much pressure is lost as it flows through the radiator (pressure loss characteristic). Essentially, the research aims to see if adding these nanoparticles can make car cooling systems more efficient by improving heat dissipation, while also understanding any potential trade-offs like increased pumping effort. This experimental work could contribute to developing better cooling technologies for vehicles.

title: Fabrication and Analysis of a Flat Plate Solar Collector using Nanofluid
description: This thesis investigates the design, construction, and performance evaluation of a flat plate solar collector, a device that harnesses sunlight to generate heat. The core innovation lies in the use of "nanofluid" instead of conventional water or glycol as the heat transfer medium. Nanofluid is a special fluid containing tiny nanoparticles, which are expected to significantly improve the collector's efficiency in absorbing solar energy and transferring heat. The research will involve fabricating the solar collector, preparing and characterizing the nanofluid, and then conducting experiments to analyze how well the nanofluid-enhanced collector performs in terms of heat transfer and overall energy output compared to traditional systems. Ultimately, this work aims to advance renewable energy technologies by demonstrating a more effective way to capture and utilize solar energy.

title: Numerical Study of a Non-Linear Suspension System Using a Geometrically Induced Spring
description: This thesis investigates the behavior of a unique car suspension system. Instead of traditional coil springs, it uses a specially shaped component to create the spring effect, which is why it's called "geometrically induced." The system is "non-linear," meaning its response isn't simple and proportional, which often makes it more complex but potentially more effective. The study will primarily use computer simulations and mathematical calculations ("numerical analysis") to understand how this innovative suspension absorbs bumps and vibrations. The goal is to design and analyze a system that could offer better ride comfort or handling characteristics by harnessing these non-linear properties.

title: Experimental Analysis on Drag Reduction by Xanthan Gum and Optimization of Concentration in a Shell and Tube Heat Exchanger
description: This thesis explores the impact of adding a common thickening agent, xanthan gum, to fluids flowing through a shell and tube heat exchanger. The main goal is to experimentally analyze how this addition can reduce the drag, or resistance, the fluid experiences. By reducing drag, less pumping energy might be needed, leading to more efficient operation. A key part of the the research will involve optimizing the concentration of xanthan gum to find the perfect amount for maximum drag reduction without negatively affecting heat transfer. Essentially, it investigates a clever way to improve the performance and energy efficiency of heat exchangers using a simple additive.

title: Numerical Analysis of Heat Transfer Augmentators with a Hole in a Tube
description: This thesis explores the performance of various heat transfer enhancement devices, specifically those shaped like augmentators with a hole, when placed inside a tube. Using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) and other numerical methods, the research aims to understand how these devices improve the efficiency of heat exchange. It will investigate the fluid flow patterns and temperature distributions around these unique augmentators to identify optimal designs for better heat transfer. Ultimately, this work contributes to the development of more efficient and compact heat exchangers, crucial for many industrial applications.

title: Fabrication and Mechanical Characterization of a Hybrid Composite Leaf Spring using Glass Fiber and Banana Fiber
description: This thesis likely investigates making a new type of car suspension spring. Instead of traditional steel, it uses a mix of glass fibers and natural banana fibers embedded in a composite material. The research would focus on how to best create this "hybrid" spring and then thoroughly test its strength, flexibility, and overall performance. The goal is probably to see if this more environmentally friendly composite spring can withstand forces and vibrations similarly to conventional springs, potentially offering a lighter and more sustainable alternative for vehicles.

title: Design and Fabrication of a Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) Based Automatic Toll Collection System
description: This thesis focuses on developing and building an automated system for collecting tolls, utilizing Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology. It will likely involve designing the RFID reader and transponder components, and integrating them into a functional system that can identify vehicles and process payments automatically. The research will delve into the practical fabrication aspects of the hardware, including the mechatronics for any physical gates or barriers, and the integration of sensors for vehicle detection. Furthermore, it will address the underlying control systems necessary to manage the entire process, ensuring efficient and reliable operation without human intervention.

title: Sleep Alarming Device for Drivers
description: This thesis focuses on designing and implementing a 'Sleep Alarming Device for Drivers' to enhance road safety. It investigates the use of various **sensors** to detect driver drowsiness, possibly including eye-tracking, heart rate, or steering pattern analysis. The core of the work involves developing **control systems** that process this sensor data and trigger timely alarms, perhaps through audio, haptic, or visual cues. Furthermore, the project likely incorporates **IoT** principles, allowing the device to connect and potentially share data for broader traffic safety initiatives. From a **Vehicle Engineering** perspective, the research considers how to seamlessly integrate this system into different vehicle types, while **Ergonomics** ensures the device is comfortable, non-distracting, and effectively alerts the driver without causing further hazards.

title: Fabrication and Analysis of Mechanical Properties of an Aluminum-Magnesium Composite
description: This thesis likely focuses on creating a new material by combining aluminum and magnesium, forming an "aluminum-magnesium composite." Researchers would probably experiment with different ways to mix these metals (fabrication) to see how it affects the final product. The core of the study would then involve testing the strength, stiffness, and other physical characteristics (mechanical properties) of this new composite. The goal is to understand how the fabrication process influences these properties, potentially aiming to develop a stronger or lighter material for various applications in materials science.

title: Ergonomic Consideration for Designing a Bus Set: Bangladesh Perspective
description: This thesis aims to improve the comfort and safety of bus passengers and drivers in Bangladesh by applying ergonomic principles to bus seat design. It will investigate current seat designs, identify shortcomings through user feedback and anthropometric data relevant to the Bangladeshi population, and propose new designs that prioritize proper posture, support, and accessibility. The research will likely involve analyzing materials, manufacturing processes, and the overall integration of the seats within the vehicle, ultimately seeking to optimize the user experience while considering local conditions and affordability. It will delve into how mechanical design can address issues like back pain and fatigue commonly experienced during long journeys in public transport.

title: Optimum Model Selection of a Spindle through Static and Dynamic Assessment using FEM to Improve the Performance of a Lathe Machine
description: This thesis aims to find the best possible design for a lathe machine's spindle, a crucial rotating part, by analyzing it under both stationary and operational conditions. It will use a computer-based simulation technique called Finite Element Analysis (FEM) to model the spindle's behavior. The research will specifically look at how the spindle performs statically (under constant load) and dynamically (while rotating and vibrating). By optimizing the spindle's design through these simulations, the goal is to significantly improve the overall accuracy and efficiency of the entire lathe machine. This work combines mechanical design, simulation, and vibration analysis to achieve peak performance.

title: Optimization of Biodiesel Production using Pumpkin Seed Oil and its Characterization
description: This thesis investigates the process of converting pumpkin seed oil into biodiesel, a cleaner burning fuel. It focuses on finding the best conditions (like temperature or catalyst amount) to make the most biodiesel efficiently. The research also involves thoroughly examining the produced biodiesel to understand its properties and ensure it meets quality standards, making it a viable renewable energy source.

title: Performance Analysis of a Diesel Engine using Diesel and Biodiesel Blends
description: This thesis investigates how a diesel engine performs when fueled by traditional diesel and various blends of diesel and biodiesel. It aims to understand if using renewable biodiesel in different mixtures affects the engine's power, efficiency, and emissions. The research will likely involve running the engine under controlled conditions and measuring key performance indicators. This work contributes to the field of sustainable energy by exploring cleaner fuel alternatives for internal combustion engines. Ultimately, it seeks to determine the practical viability and benefits of transitioning to biodiesel blends.

title: Design of a Fuzzy-Based Intelligent Controller for an Air Conditioning System
description: This thesis likely focuses on creating a smarter air conditioning system. Instead of simply turning on or off, it aims to design a special "brain" using fuzzy logic, a type of artificial intelligence that mimics human decision-making, allowing for more nuanced control. This intelligent controller would learn to optimize cooling, maintain comfortable temperatures more efficiently, and potentially save energy by adapting to various conditions and user preferences. The research bridges the gap between AI and practical HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning) applications, ultimately contributing to more automated and efficient climate control.

title: Dependency of Tensile Behaviors of Cu3Sn on Crystal Size and Direction: A Molecular Dynamics Study
description: This thesis explores how the tensile behavior of Cu3Sn, a type of intermetallic compound, is affected by its internal structure. Specifically, it uses computer simulations, called Molecular Dynamics, to understand how the size of its individual crystals and their orientation influence how strong it is and how it deforms when pulled. The research aims to uncover the fundamental relationship between these microscopic structural features and the material's macroscopic mechanical properties, such as its strength and ductility, at an atomic level. This understanding could be crucial for designing materials with improved mechanical performance.

title: Design and Fabrication of an Automatic Irrigation System using Arduino and a Soil Moisture Sensor
description: This thesis focuses on creating an automatic watering system for plants. It will involve designing and building a device that uses an Arduino microcontroller as its "brain" to control when and how much water is dispensed. A key component will be a soil moisture sensor, which tells the system if the soil is dry and needs watering. The project aims to automate the irrigation process, eliminating the need for manual watering and potentially saving water. It combines elements of electronics, programming, and mechanical design to achieve a functional and efficient system. The work involves both the conceptual design and the physical construction of the system, showcasing practical application of control principles. Ultimately, this research contributes to the field of smart agriculture and home automation.

title: Design and Analysis of an LPG Cylinder using E-Glass Epoxy Composite Materials as per ASME Standards
description: This thesis investigates the potential of replacing traditional metal LPG cylinders with lighter, safer ones made from E-Glass Epoxy composite materials. It will involve designing the composite cylinder, ensuring it meets the stringent safety requirements outlined by ASME standards. A significant portion of the work will focus on analyzing the cylinder's behavior under various pressures and loads using Finite Element Analysis (FEA) to predict stress distribution and potential failure points. The research aims to demonstrate the viability of composites for this application, offering advantages in terms of reduced weight and improved corrosion resistance, ultimately contributing to safer and more efficient LPG storage solutions.

title: Influence of Neem Bio-Diesel and Diesel Blend on a Single-Cylinder Diesel Engine
description: This thesis investigates how a specific blend of neem bio-diesel and regular diesel fuel affects the performance of a small, single-cylinder diesel engine. Researchers will likely be comparing the engine's power, fuel efficiency, and emissions when running on this blended fuel versus traditional diesel. The study aims to understand if neem bio-diesel can be a viable and environmentally friendly alternative fuel source. It delves into the combustion characteristics and overall operational behavior of the engine with this renewable energy blend. The findings could highlight the potential of sustainable biofuels for transportation and power generation.

title: Fabrication of a Thermostatic Expansion Valve
description: This thesis delves into the practical creation of a thermostatic expansion valve, a crucial component in refrigeration and HVAC systems. It likely covers the entire process, from initial mechanical design and material selection to the actual manufacturing steps. The research would focus on fabricating a functional valve that precisely controls refrigerant flow, ensuring optimal system performance. This involves understanding the principles of refrigeration and thermodynamics to design a valve that can accurately respond to temperature changes. Ultimately, the thesis aims to demonstrate the successful fabrication of such a device, potentially including testing and performance evaluation.

title: Fabrication and Property Analysis of Natural Fiber, Glass Fiber, and Epoxy Resin-Based Hybrid Composition
description: This thesis focuses on creating and understanding a new type of strong material, or "composite." It combines natural fibers (like those from plants), glass fibers, and a binding agent called epoxy resin to make a hybrid material. The research will likely involve fabricating these composites in different ways, then thoroughly testing their properties. This includes examining their structure and, importantly, how they perform under stress, such as their strength and stiffness, to determine their potential applications.

title: Hemodynamics and Numerical Simulation of Physiological Blood Flow through a Semicircular Shaped Stenosed Artery
description: This thesis explores the impact of a specific type of narrowing, or stenosis, on blood flow within an artery. Focusing on a "semicircular" shaped constriction, it uses advanced computer modeling, known as numerical simulation, to understand how blood moves and exerts pressure in this compromised vessel. The research delves into hemodynamics, which is the study of blood flow dynamics, combining principles of fluid mechanics and computational fluid dynamics to analyze complex physiological processes. Essentially, it's about using powerful computer simulations to mimic and understand how blood navigates a partially blocked artery, potentially shedding light on cardiovascular diseases.

title: Numerical Simulation of a Centrifugal Pump Impeller with a Splitting Blade
description: This thesis explores the performance of a centrifugal pump's rotating part, the impeller, when a special design feature—a "splitting blade"—is added. Instead of a single, full blade, a smaller, secondary blade is inserted between the main ones to potentially improve how water flows through the pump. Using computer models and calculations (numerical simulation), the research will analyze how this design affects efficiency, pressure, and flow patterns within the pump. It aims to understand if the splitting blade can reduce energy losses or improve the pump's overall operation. Essentially, it's about using virtual experiments to optimize pump design for better fluid movement.

title: Performance Analysis of a Flat Plate Solar Collector using Nanofluid
description: This thesis investigates how a flat plate solar collector, a device that harnesses sunlight to heat water, performs when a special fluid called "nanofluid" is used instead of traditional water. It aims to understand if these nanofluids, which are engineered with tiny particles, can significantly improve the collector's ability to transfer heat and thus make it more efficient at converting solar energy into usable heat. The research will likely involve analyzing fluid flow patterns and heat transfer characteristics within the collector to determine the optimal nanofluid composition for enhanced performance. Essentially, it's about making solar water heaters better by using advanced fluids.

title: Experimental Study on Thermal Characteristics of Aluminum Honeycomb Heat Pipe Regulators
description: This thesis explores the thermal behavior of aluminum honeycomb structures when used as heat pipe regulators. It focuses on understanding how these unique composite materials transfer heat, aiming to improve cooling systems and heat exchanger designs. The research likely involves experiments to characterize the material's ability to absorb, dissipate, and regulate heat. Ultimately, the goal is to develop more efficient cooling solutions by leveraging the specific properties of aluminum honeycomb in heat pipe applications.

title: CFD Analysis of a NACA 4418 Airfoil with Various Winglets
description: This thesis explores the impact of different winglet designs on a specific airplane wing shape, the NACA 4418. Using computer simulations, or "Computational Fluid Dynamics" (CFD), the research will analyze how air flows around this wing and its various winglet attachments. The goal is to understand how these small vertical extensions at the wingtip affect the wing's performance, particularly in terms of lift and drag. By testing different winglet configurations, the study aims to identify which designs might make the airfoil more efficient, perhaps leading to better fuel economy or improved flight characteristics. Essentially, it's about using virtual experiments to optimize wing designs for future aircraft.

title: Effects and Validation of an Inerter-Based Suspension System in Regular and Agricultural Automobiles
description: This thesis explores the development and testing of a new car suspension system that uses a special mechanical device called an "inerter." The research focuses on how this inerter-based system improves ride comfort and handling for both regular passenger cars and heavy agricultural vehicles like tractors. It will likely involve designing the system, analyzing how it reduces vibrations, and then using computer simulations and potentially real-world experiments to prove its effectiveness and validate the design for practical use. The study aims to demonstrate the benefits of this innovative suspension technology across different vehicle types.

title: Experimental Investigation of Cycling Characteristics of a Rechargeable NiMH Battery
description: This thesis investigates how a rechargeable Nickel-Metal Hydride (NiMH) battery performs over many charging and discharging cycles. Researchers will experimentally examine key characteristics such as capacity fade, voltage degradation, and internal resistance changes as the battery is used repeatedly. The goal is to understand what happens to the battery's internal materials and chemistry that causes it to degrade over time. This research will help engineers design more durable NiMH batteries for various applications by identifying the factors limiting their lifespan.

title: Fabrication and Mechanical Characterization of Bamboo-Sugarcane Fiber Reinforced Hybrid Epoxy Composites
description: This thesis investigates the creation and performance of new composite materials made from natural fibers. Specifically, it focuses on combining bamboo and sugarcane fibers, embedding them within an epoxy resin to form a strong, lightweight material. The research will detail the methods used to make these "hybrid" composites, from preparing the fibers to molding the final product. A key part of the study involves thoroughly testing the mechanical properties, such as how strong and stiff the composites are under various stresses. The ultimate goal is to understand if these natural fiber composites can be a sustainable alternative to traditional materials, offering a greener solution for various engineering applications.

title: Design and Implementation of a Smart Home
description: This thesis explores the design and implementation of a smart home system. It focuses on using Internet of Things (IoT) devices for home automation, allowing users to remotely control various appliances and environments. The research likely involves integrating different sensors to gather data about the home's conditions, such as temperature, light, or occupancy. Furthermore, it might delve into control systems that respond to this data, automatically adjusting settings for comfort, energy efficiency, or security. The thesis could also investigate the application of Artificial Intelligence (AI) for predictive automation, learning user preferences, and optimizing home functions autonomously.

title: Comparison of Anodizing, Electrodeposition, and Powder Coating on Aluminum Alloy
description: This thesis explores the impact of different surface treatments—anodizing, electrodeposition, and powder coating—on aluminum alloys. It will compare how each method changes the material's properties. The research will likely involve looking at the microstructure, measuring mechanical strength like hardness and wear resistance, and assessing how well the coatings protect against corrosion. Ultimately, the goal is to understand which surface treatment is most effective for different applications, considering factors like durability and protection.

title: Performance Using Nozzle Arrangement
description: This thesis explores the impact of different nozzle arrangements on the performance of a system. It likely investigates how varying the number, spacing, and geometry of nozzles influences fluid flow characteristics and efficiency. Through the lens of fluid mechanics and aerodynamics, the research aims to optimize the mechanical design of these nozzle configurations to achieve superior performance metrics. This could involve maximizing thrust, minimizing energy loss, or enhancing mixing processes, ultimately contributing to more efficient and effective engineering applications.

title: Investigation of the Energy Absorption Characteristics of the Tropical Jackfruit-Inspired Sandwich Panel
description: This thesis investigates how a special type of sandwich panel, designed to mimic the tough yet flexible structure of a tropical jackfruit, absorbs energy. It will likely explore making these panels using natural fibers, aiming to understand their mechanical properties and how effectively they can dissipate energy, perhaps for applications like impact protection. The research could delve into the specific arrangement and composition of materials within the panel that allow it to absorb impacts without breaking, drawing inspiration from the jackfruit's unique rind. Essentially, it's about creating a strong, lightweight, and energy-absorbing material inspired by nature.

title: Numerical Analysis of an Initial Value Problem for an Ordinary Differential Equation with the Fourth-Order Runge-Kutta Method
description: This thesis likely delves into solving a specific type of mathematical problem called an "initial value problem" for an "ordinary differential equation." It focuses on using a popular computational technique, the "fourth-order Runge-Kutta method," to find approximate numerical solutions. The research would involve analyzing how accurately and efficiently this method can simulate the behavior described by the equation, especially when starting from a known initial state. Essentially, it's about using computers to understand and predict how things change over time based on given rules and a starting point.

title: Fabrication and Performance Analysis of a Hydroxy Gas Generation using Various Electrodes in Different Electrolyte Conditions, Temperatures, and Times
description: This thesis explores the efficient generation of hydroxy gas, a promising renewable energy source, through electrolysis. The research focuses on designing and building a system that produces this gas. It investigates how different electrode materials and various electrolyte solutions affect the process. Furthermore, the study analyzes the influence of temperature and reaction time on gas production performance. Ultimately, this work aims to optimize the fabrication and operation of a hydroxy gas generator, contributing to cleaner energy solutions.

title: Ergonomic Analysis for Designing a Human Hauler Seat: Bangladesh Perspective
description: This thesis will investigate how to design a more comfortable and safer seat for human haulers in Bangladesh, focusing on ergonomic principles. It aims to analyze the current seating conditions and the biomechanical stresses on drivers and passengers. By applying principles of mechanical design and optimization, the research will propose an improved seat design that reduces discomfort and potential health issues. The ultimate goal is to enhance the well-being of human hauler occupants while considering the unique local context and challenges of vehicle engineering in Bangladesh.

title: Fabrication and Analysis of Semiautomatic Pigment Mixing for Paint Production
description: This thesis focuses on developing and evaluating a new system for mixing pigments in paint production. It will involve designing and building a machine that automates part of the mixing process, aiming to make it more efficient and consistent. The research will likely cover the mechanical components, the electronic controls that make it "semiautomatic," and how well it performs in creating accurately colored paint. Ultimately, it aims to demonstrate the practical benefits of introducing a more automated approach to a specific step in the manufacturing of paint.

title: Fabrication of a Motorized Assistive Wheelchair for Easy Shifting of a Physically Handicapped Person
description: This thesis focuses on the creation of a motorized assistive wheelchair designed to make it significantly easier for physically handicapped individuals to move or "shift" themselves. It will likely detail the mechanical design and fabrication process of the wheelchair, including the selection and integration of components for its motorized operation. The research will explore automation aspects, perhaps incorporating features for simplified control and maneuvering. Furthermore, it might delve into the biomechanical considerations to ensure the design is ergonomic and effectively supports the user, ultimately contributing to the field of biomedical engineering by improving mobility and independence for those with physical disabilities.

title: Numerical Investigation of the Effect of a Wavy Porous Insert and CuO/Water Nanofluid on the Heat Transfer Characteristic of Flow through a Circular Tube
description: This thesis investigates how to improve heat transfer in a circular pipe. It specifically looks at two ways to do this: adding a special wavy, porous material inside the pipe and using a "nanofluid" instead of plain water. Nanofluid is water with tiny copper oxide particles mixed in, which can enhance heat transfer. The research will use computer simulations (numerical investigation) to understand how these changes affect how well heat moves through the system. Essentially, it's about finding better and more efficient ways to cool or heat things using smart pipe designs and advanced fluids.

title: Optimizing an Existing Airfoil Shape with a Genetic Algorithm and Validating it by Wind Tunnel Experiment
description: This thesis explores how to improve an existing aircraft wing (airfoil) shape using a clever computer program inspired by natural evolution, called a Genetic Algorithm. Instead of manually designing variations, the algorithm will automatically generate and test many different shapes to find the best performing one. This "optimization" process, likely involving computer simulations (Computational Fluid Dynamics or CFD) to predict airflow, aims to make the airfoil more efficient. Finally, the best new airfoil design will be physically built and tested in a wind tunnel to confirm its performance in real-world conditions, validating the computer-generated improvements. This research combines artificial intelligence with practical aerodynamics to enhance aircraft design.

title: Design and Fabrication of an IoT-Based Real-Time Water Quality and Contamination Monitoring System for the Karnaphuli River
description: This thesis focuses on creating a smart system using internet-connected devices (IoT) to continuously check the water quality of the Karnaphuli River. It involves designing and building physical sensors and equipment to detect various pollutants and contaminants in real-time. The goal is to develop an automated monitoring solution that can provide immediate information about the river's health, helping with pollution control efforts. Essentially, it's about building a practical, hands-on tool to keep a constant eye on the Karnaphuli River's water, using technology to identify pollution quickly.

title: Fabrication and Mechanical Properties Characterization of Banana Empty Fruit Branch Reinforced Epoxy Resin
description: This thesis investigates the creation and characteristics of a new material made from natural banana fibers. It focuses on taking the empty fruit branches of bananas, which are often considered waste, and using them to strengthen epoxy resin. The research will likely involve different methods to combine these materials (fabrication) and then thoroughly test the resulting composite's strength, stiffness, and other mechanical behaviors. Ultimately, this work aims to understand if these natural banana fibers can serve as an effective, eco-friendly reinforcement in engineering applications, potentially offering a sustainable alternative to synthetic materials.

title: Study of Heat Transfer Performance Characteristics of a Hybrid Nanofluid used as a Coolant in a Car Radiator
description: This thesis investigates how well a special liquid, called a "hybrid nanofluid," transfers heat when used as a coolant in a car's radiator. It aims to understand the fluid's unique cooling abilities compared to traditional coolants, potentially leading to more efficient vehicle cooling systems. The study will likely involve experiments or simulations to measure how effectively this nanofluid dissipates heat from the engine. By analyzing its "heat transfer performance characteristics," the research could reveal if hybrid nanofluids are a viable and improved solution for automotive cooling. Ultimately, it seeks to contribute to advancements in cooling technology within vehicle engineering.

title: Optimization of Biodiesel Production from Pithraj Seed Oil using a Response Surface Methodology
description: This thesis investigates how to make biodiesel more efficiently from a new source: Pithraj seed oil. It aims to find the best conditions – like temperature or catalyst amount – to produce the most biodiesel with the least waste. By using a "Response Surface Methodology," the research will systematically test various combinations to pinpoint the optimal process. This work contributes to developing sustainable and renewable energy sources, ultimately making biofuel production more cost-effective and environmentally friendly.

title: Production of Biofuel from Plant Biomass by a Fermentation Process using Commercial Brewer's Yeast
description: This thesis investigates the potential of producing biofuel from readily available plant biomass, a sustainable energy source. It specifically focuses on a fermentation process, a biological method, utilizing commercial brewer's yeast, a common and affordable microorganism. The research likely explores the efficiency of this yeast in converting plant material into biofuel, aiming to develop a renewable energy solution. This approach contributes to sustainability by reducing reliance on fossil fuels and could potentially offer a method for waste management by utilizing agricultural or forestry residues. Ultimately, the thesis seeks to contribute to the development of eco-friendly biofuel production methods.

title: Corrosion Analysis of Different Shapes of Aluminum in Various Solutions
description: This thesis explores how different shapes of aluminum corrode when exposed to various liquid environments. It will investigate if the shape of the aluminum, like a flat sheet versus a curved tube, influences how quickly or severely it degrades. The research will involve putting these aluminum samples into different solutions, such as saltwater or acidic liquids, to observe and measure the resulting corrosion. Ultimately, this study aims to understand the impact of both shape and solution on aluminum's durability, providing insights into its practical applications.

title: Study of Safety Issues for Rechargeable Lithium-Ion Batteries: Investigation of External Short Circuits
description: This thesis investigates the safety concerns associated with rechargeable lithium-ion batteries, specifically focusing on what happens when an external short circuit occurs. It delves into the material science behind battery components and how their properties contribute to safety or failure during such events. The study likely utilizes simulations to model the heat transfer generated by the short circuit, understanding how temperature rise can lead to thermal runaway. Furthermore, it might examine the mechanical properties of battery components and how they withstand the stress and pressure built up during a short, aiming to design safer energy storage solutions.

title: Fabrication and Analysis of a Flat Plate Solar Collector with a Reflector using TiO2-Water Nanofluid
description: This thesis investigates the design, construction, and performance evaluation of a flat plate solar collector, enhanced with a reflector. The core innovation lies in the use of a cutting-edge heat transfer fluid: a nanofluid made by dispersing titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanoparticles in water. The research likely focuses on how this TiO2-water nanofluid improves the collector's efficiency in absorbing solar energy compared to using plain water. It will also analyze the additional benefits of incorporating a reflector to concentrate sunlight onto the collector. Ultimately, this work aims to develop a more efficient and sustainable solar thermal system for various applications.

title: Experimental Investigation of the Water Hammer Effect in a Pipeline System
description: This thesis explores the sudden pressure surges, known as water hammer, that can occur in pipeline systems when fluid flow is rapidly stopped or changed. It involves conducting experiments to observe and measure these pressure waves, analyzing how they interact with the pipeline structure, and understanding the resulting vibrations and stresses on the pipes. The research aims to provide practical insights into preventing or mitigating the damaging effects of water hammer, ultimately contributing to safer and more reliable pipeline designs.

title: Design and Fabrication of an Underwater Acoustic Hydrophone
description: This thesis delves into the practical development of an underwater acoustic hydrophone, a device used to detect sound in water. It will likely cover the complete process, from the initial conceptualization and mechanical design of the sensor's physical structure to the selection and integration of acoustic materials and electronic components. The research will also explore the fabrication techniques employed to build a working prototype, including any specialized manufacturing processes required for underwater applications. Ultimately, the thesis aims to demonstrate a functional hydrophone, potentially analyzing its performance in detecting and measuring underwater sound signals.

title: Production and Characterization of Biodiesel from Flaxseed Oil
description: This thesis explores the potential of flaxseed oil as a sustainable source for biodiesel production. It will detail the process of converting flaxseed oil into biodiesel, likely through chemical reactions like transesterification. A significant part of the research will involve characterizing the produced biodiesel, analyzing its quality and properties to ensure it meets fuel standards. This includes examining factors like viscosity, density, and energy content. Ultimately, the study aims to assess the viability and benefits of flaxseed oil biodiesel as a renewable and environmentally friendly alternative to conventional fossil fuels, contributing to the global push for sustainable energy.

title: The Effect of Surface Modification of a NACA 0012 Airfoil on Aerodynamic Performance Improvement
description: This thesis explores the impact of altering the surface of a standard NACA 0012 airfoil on its aerodynamic performance. It will likely investigate how applying different coatings or textures, or even changing the material's surface properties, can reduce drag and increase lift. Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) simulations will be a key tool to model these changes and predict their effects without needing physical prototypes. The research aims to identify optimal surface modifications, potentially drawing on materials science principles, to significantly improve the airfoil's efficiency for various flight conditions. Ultimately, this work seeks to find innovative ways to make aircraft wings perform better, leading to fuel savings or enhanced maneuverability.

title: A Numerical Analysis of a NACA 0015 Airfoil with Different Types of Flaps
description: This thesis explores the impact of various flap configurations on a NACA 0015 airfoil using numerical analysis. It will likely investigate how different flap types, such as split, slotted, or Fowler flaps, alter the airflow around the airfoil. The research will employ computational fluid dynamics (CFD) to simulate these interactions, providing insights into changes in lift, drag, and pressure distribution. Ultimately, the study aims to understand the aerodynamic performance of this specific airfoil under varying flap conditions, which is crucial for aircraft design and efficiency. This work falls under the umbrella of fluid mechanics and aerodynamics, utilizing simulations to predict real-world behavior.

title: A Computational Analysis of Aerodynamic Performance and Thermal Comfort of a Bicycle Helmet
description: This thesis explores how well a bicycle helmet performs in two key areas: cutting through the air efficiently and keeping the rider cool and comfortable. Using advanced computer simulations, specifically Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD), the research will analyze airflow patterns around different helmet designs to understand their aerodynamic drag. Simultaneously, it will investigate heat transfer within the helmet to evaluate its ability to manage temperature and provide thermal comfort. The study aims to identify optimal helmet features that balance these two critical performance aspects, potentially leading to designs that are both fast and comfortable for cyclists.

title: Dependency of Tensile Behavior of Ag3Sn on Crystal Size and Direction: A Molecular Dynamics Study
description: This thesis explores how the strength and stretching behavior (tensile behavior) of a specific material, Ag3Sn, is affected by two key factors: the size of its individual crystal grains and the direction in which these grains are oriented. Using a computer simulation method called Molecular Dynamics, the research will essentially "pull apart" virtual samples of Ag3Sn to see how these microscopic characteristics influence its macroscopic mechanical properties. It aims to understand, at an atomic level, why Ag3Sn might be stronger or weaker, or stretch more or less, depending on its internal structure. This knowledge is crucial for designing materials with specific desired properties, especially in applications where Ag3Sn is used, such as dental amalgams or solder joints.

title: Study of the Cycling Behavior of Rechargeable Lithium-Ion Batteries at Room Temperature
description: This thesis investigates how rechargeable lithium-ion batteries perform over many charge and discharge cycles when used at typical room temperatures. It likely focuses on understanding the underlying changes within the battery materials, potentially using advanced characterization techniques to observe how the active components degrade or transform. The study might also explore how physical stresses or mechanical properties of the battery materials evolve with cycling, and could involve computer simulations to predict or explain these behaviors, ultimately aiming to improve battery lifespan and reliability.

title: IoT-Based HVAC Monitoring System for a Smart Laboratory
description: This thesis likely focuses on designing and implementing a system that uses internet-connected devices (IoT) to oversee and manage the heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) within a modern laboratory setting. It will probably involve deploying various sensors to collect data on temperature, humidity, and air quality, and then using this information to automate and optimize the laboratory's climate control. The goal is likely to create a "smart" laboratory environment where the HVAC system can be monitored remotely, adjust automatically for comfort and energy efficiency, and potentially alert users to issues, thus enhancing the overall control and automation of the lab's climate.

title: Modification and Evaluation of a Savonius Water Turbine for Power Production
description: This thesis explores improving the design and performance of a Savonius water turbine, a type of vertical-axis turbine, to generate electricity more efficiently. It will likely involve modifying the turbine's shape or components to optimize how it captures energy from flowing water. The research will then evaluate these modifications through experiments or simulations, focusing on factors like power output and overall efficiency. Ultimately, the goal is to develop a more effective and practical renewable energy solution for power production, contributing to the field of small-scale hydropower.

title: Thermal Enhancement of a Flat Plate Solar Collector using Corrugated Dimple Riser Tubes with V-Type Twisted Tape Inserts
description: This thesis explores innovative ways to make flat plate solar collectors more efficient at heating water. It investigates using specially designed "corrugated dimple riser tubes," which have textured surfaces to improve heat transfer from the sun. Furthermore, it examines the addition of "V-type twisted tape inserts" inside these tubes, which swirl the water to maximize heat absorption. The research will likely involve computer simulations (Computational Fluid Dynamics) to understand the fluid flow and heat exchange, aiming to optimize the design for better performance. Ultimately, this work contributes to advancing renewable energy technologies by making solar thermal systems more effective and practical.

title: Aerodynamic Performance Improvement of Heavy Vehicles by Design Modification
description: This thesis explores how to make heavy vehicles like trucks and buses more fuel-efficient and stable by changing their exterior design. It will use advanced computer simulations, known as Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD), to understand how air flows around these large vehicles. By analyzing these airflows, the research aims to identify specific design modifications that can reduce aerodynamic drag, which is the resistance caused by air. Ultimately, the goal is to optimize the vehicle's shape to improve its overall performance, leading to significant fuel savings and potentially enhanced safety.

title: A Comparative Computational Study on Conventional and Perforated Cylindrical and Square Pin Fin Arrays
description: This thesis explores how different shapes of cooling fins, specifically solid and holed cylinders and squares, affect how well they transfer heat. Using computational fluid dynamics, the research will simulate air or fluid flowing over these fins to understand their efficiency. The study aims to compare their performance in dissipating heat, which is crucial for designing better heat exchangers and cooling systems. Ultimately, it seeks to identify which fin configurations are most effective for various applications, contributing to advancements in heat transfer and fluid mechanics.

title: Experimental Investigation of Vibration and Noise of an Internal Combustion Engine
description: This thesis delves into the complex world of engine dynamics, specifically focusing on how an internal combustion engine's operation generates both vibrations and noise. It likely involves setting up experiments to measure and analyze these phenomena directly from a running engine. The research would aim to understand the sources of these vibrations and noise, perhaps linking them to the combustion process itself or other mechanical aspects of the engine. Ultimately, the findings could contribute to developing quieter and smoother engines, improving vehicle comfort, and advancing the field of acoustic and vibration control in automotive engineering.

title: Fabrication and Mechanical Properties Characterization of Coir Fiber, Biber, and Betel Nut Husk Fiber Reinforced Hybrid Polyester Composite
description: This thesis explores the creation and characteristics of new, eco-friendly materials. It focuses on combining polyester resin with natural fibers like coir, biber, and betel nut husk to form "hybrid composites." The research will involve fabricating these composite materials in the lab. A key part of the study will be to understand their mechanical properties, such as strength and stiffness, through various tests. Ultimately, this work aims to evaluate if these natural fiber composites could be viable alternatives for various applications, contributing to sustainable material development.

title: Experimental and Numerical Study of NREL Airfoils with Variation of Thickness and Low Wind Conditions
description: This thesis investigates how different thicknesses of NREL (National Renewable Energy Laboratory) wind turbine airfoils perform, especially when the wind is slow. It will use both physical experiments and computer simulations (Computational Fluid Dynamics) to understand the airflow around these modified airfoils. The goal is to optimize airfoil designs for improved efficiency and power generation in low wind speed environments, a crucial aspect for wind energy production. The study will involve detailed fluid mechanics analysis and numerical methods to predict and validate the airfoil behavior.

title: Waste Heat Recovery by using an Automotive Exhaust Thermoelectric Generator
description: This thesis investigates a clever way to capture wasted energy from cars. Imagine a device attached to a car's exhaust pipe that can turn the hot gases into electricity using special materials. This electricity could then power various car components or even be stored in a battery, reducing the load on the engine and potentially improving fuel efficiency. Essentially, it's about making vehicle exhaust heat a valuable source of renewable energy, transforming a common waste product into useful power. By converting heat directly into electricity, this system offers a promising avenue for improving vehicle energy efficiency and contributing to sustainable transportation solutions.

title: Numerical Investigation of a Modified NACA 0018 Airfoil using Bumps at Low Reynolds Number
description: This thesis investigates how adding small bumps to a standard NACA 0018 airfoil changes its performance, particularly at low Reynolds numbers, which are typical for small drones or high-altitude aircraft. It will use computer simulations (Computational Fluid Dynamics, CFD) to numerically analyze the airflow around this modified wing. The goal is to understand if these bumps can improve aerodynamic efficiency, perhaps by controlling flow separation or reducing drag, under conditions where traditional airfoils might struggle. Essentially, it's a computational experiment to see if a simple physical modification can enhance how a wing flies.

title: Numerical Investigation on the Thermal Performance Characteristic of a Tube Heat Exchanger Equipped with a Rectangular Cut Twisted Tape Insert with Squared Perforation
description: This thesis explores the impact of a unique internal design on the efficiency of a tube heat exchanger. Specifically, it investigates how a "rectangular cut twisted tape insert with squared perforation" enhances heat transfer within the tube. The research will likely involve computer simulations (numerical analysis/CFD) to model fluid flow and temperature distribution, rather than physical experiments. The goal is to understand how this particular tape insert design improves the heat exchanger's ability to transfer thermal energy, which is crucial for various industrial applications. Essentially, it's about optimizing heat exchanger performance through a clever internal modification, all done virtually.

title: Fabrication of Corrugated Roofing Sheets with an Epoxy-Banana Fiber Composite
description: This thesis investigates the creation of a new type of roofing material: corrugated sheets made from an epoxy-banana fiber composite. The research focuses on the "fabrication" process, exploring how to effectively combine epoxy resin with natural banana fibers to form a strong and durable "composite." It aims to assess the material's properties, such as its strength and resistance to environmental factors, to determine its suitability as an alternative to traditional roofing materials. Ultimately, the study contributes to "materials science" by developing "natural fiber composites" that could be a more sustainable and potentially cost-effective option for "manufacturing" roofing sheets.

title: Fabrication and Study of Mechanical Properties of Bagasse and Jute Fiber Reinforced Polyester Composites Hybridized with Glass Fiber
description: This thesis investigates the creation and performance of new composite materials. It focuses on using natural fibers like bagasse and jute, which are abundant and sustainable, as reinforcements in a polyester resin. To potentially enhance their strength, these natural fiber composites are further hybridized with glass fibers. The research likely involves fabricating these different composite variations and then thoroughly testing their mechanical properties, such as their strength, stiffness, and how they behave under stress. Ultimately, the goal is to understand how the combination and proportion of these fibers influence the material's overall performance, potentially leading to the development of eco-friendly yet robust engineering materials.

title: Improving the Efficiency of Cathodic Protection for Marine Structures
description: This thesis aims to enhance the effectiveness of cathodic protection, a crucial method for preventing corrosion in marine structures like ships and offshore platforms. It will likely investigate new materials or improved system designs to make this protection more efficient. The research might involve optimizing how the protective current is applied, possibly using advanced control systems and smart sensors to monitor performance in real-time. Ultimately, the goal is to reduce maintenance costs and extend the lifespan of these valuable assets by better understanding and controlling the corrosion process.

title: A Computational Study and Analysis of Carotid Artery Stenosis
description: This thesis explores how blood flow changes in the carotid artery when it narrows, a condition called stenosis. Using computer models, it investigates the forces and pressures on the artery walls caused by this narrowing. The study aims to understand how these physical changes might contribute to the progression of the disease. It will likely use advanced simulations to mimic blood movement and analyze its effects. This research could help improve the diagnosis and treatment of carotid artery stenosis by providing a deeper understanding of its biomechanical aspects.

title: Design and Development of Spilled Oil Cleanup Mechanisms for a Sustainable Environment and Eco-Friendly Marine Life
description: This thesis aims to develop innovative solutions for cleaning up oil spills, focusing on designs that are both effective and gentle on marine ecosystems. It will involve creating new mechanical systems to efficiently remove spilled oil, considering how they interact with water currents and the ocean environment. The core idea is to design these cleanup mechanisms in a way that minimizes further harm, promoting a healthier ocean and supporting diverse marine life. Ultimately, this research contributes to a more sustainable future by addressing a major source of marine pollution through smart, environmentally conscious engineering.

title: Analysis of Mechanical Properties of Various Welding Joints
description: This thesis delves into understanding how different types of welded connections behave when subjected to various forces. It aims to characterize the strength, ductility, and toughness of these welding joints, which are crucial mechanical properties. Researchers will likely employ material characterization techniques, such as tensile, fatigue, and impact testing, to evaluate their performance. The study will contribute to the fields of materials science and solid mechanics by providing insights into the structural integrity and reliability of welded structures. Ultimately, this research could lead to improved welding practices and safer engineered designs.

title: Experimental Investigation of a Shell and Tube Type Heat Exchanger Embedded with Phase Change Material and a Spiral Fin
description: This thesis likely investigates how to make heat exchangers, specifically the common shell and tube type, more efficient for applications like cooling systems or HVAC. It focuses on two key enhancements: embedding Phase Change Materials (PCMs) to store and release heat, thereby smoothing out temperature fluctuations or extending cooling capacity, and incorporating a spiral fin to improve heat transfer by encouraging better fluid mixing. The research would experimentally explore how these modifications collectively affect the heat exchanger's performance, aiming to develop a more effective and potentially more compact system for various thermal management needs. Ultimately, it seeks to optimize heat transfer and energy storage capabilities within these crucial components.

title: Analysis of Biosorption of Lead by Green Leaves of Ziziphus Mauritiana
description: This thesis investigates a natural solution to lead pollution using a common plant. It explores how the green leaves of the *Ziziphus Mauritiana* tree, also known as the Jujube or Ber tree, can effectively absorb lead from contaminated water. The research aims to understand the mechanisms behind this "biosorption" process, potentially offering an eco-friendly and cost-effective method for cleaning up lead in the environment. By utilizing readily available plant material, this study contributes to sustainable waste management and pollution control, examining the material's characteristics to optimize its performance. Ultimately, it seeks to provide a greener alternative for detoxifying water polluted with heavy metals.

title: Numerical Analysis on Cavitation Noise and Fluid-Structure Interaction of AU-Outline, Gawan Series, and B-Series Marine Propellers
description: This thesis delves into understanding and predicting the noise generated by marine propellers, specifically focusing on the "AU-Outline, Gawan Series, and B-Series" designs. It uses advanced computer simulations (numerical analysis and computational fluid dynamics) to study how water flows around these propellers and how that flow creates cavitation – the formation and collapse of bubbles. A key aspect is investigating "fluid-structure interaction," meaning how the water's forces affect the propeller's vibrations, and in turn, how those vibrations influence the cavitation and the resulting noise. Ultimately, this research aims to improve propeller design to reduce noise pollution and enhance performance.

title: Fabrication and Mechanical Properties Characterization of Alkali-Treated Jute, Palmyra Palm Leaf Stalk Fiber Reinforced Hybrid Epoxy Composites
description: This thesis likely investigates making new, eco-friendly composite materials using epoxy resin reinforced with natural fibers. Specifically, it will focus on jute and palmyra palm leaf stalk fibers, which are pre-treated with alkali to improve their bonding with the epoxy. The research will then analyze the strength, stiffness, and other mechanical behaviors of these hybrid composites. The goal is to understand how these natural fibers, particularly after alkali treatment, contribute to the overall performance of the resulting composite material, potentially for sustainable engineering applications.

title: Suppression of Vortex-Induced Vibration of a Square Cylinder with Secondary Control Rods
description: This thesis investigates methods to stop a square rod from wiggling excessively when fluid, like wind or water, flows around it. This wiggling, called vortex-induced vibration, can cause problems for structures like bridges or pipelines. The research focuses on using smaller, secondary rods placed strategically near the main square cylinder to suppress these unwanted vibrations. Essentially, it explores how these additional rods can disrupt the swirling fluid patterns that cause the wiggling, thereby making the main structure more stable and preventing potential damage or failure. It delves into understanding the fluid behavior, the resulting vibrations, and how the secondary rods can effectively control them.

title: Design and Fabrication of a Wave Energy Converter using a Slider-Crank Mechanism
description: This thesis focuses on developing a device that harnesses energy from ocean waves. It specifically investigates how a "slider-crank mechanism," similar to what makes an engine piston move, can be adapted to convert the up-and-down motion of waves into useful energy. The research will likely cover the conceptual design of this wave energy converter, followed by the actual construction of a prototype. Key aspects will include the mechanical engineering principles behind its operation and how the moving parts translate wave motion into electricity or other usable power, contributing to renewable energy solutions.

title: Experimental Study of Heat Transfer Enhancement of a Car Radiator with a Water-Based Nanofluid
description: This thesis explores the potential of using water-based nanofluids to improve the cooling efficiency of car radiators. It investigates how adding tiny nanoparticles to water, which then flows through a car's cooling system, might enhance its ability to dissipate heat. The study will likely involve experiments to compare the heat transfer performance of a traditional coolant with that of a nanofluid in a car radiator. The aim is to determine if these enhanced fluids can lead to better engine cooling, potentially improving vehicle performance and fuel efficiency. This research falls under the broader fields of heat transfer, nanofluids, and vehicle engineering, focusing on optimizing heat exchangers for cooling systems.

title: Comparative Study of Fiber Orientation of Jute-Banana Hybrid Epoxy Composites
description: This thesis investigates a new type of material called "jute-banana hybrid epoxy composites," which are made by combining natural fibers (jute and banana) with a plastic-like substance (epoxy). The main focus is to understand how the direction or "orientation" of these fibers affects the material's overall properties. Specifically, it will compare how different arrangements of jute and banana fibers impact the strength and other characteristics of these eco-friendly composites. The study aims to characterize these materials, providing insights into their potential use in various applications by understanding their mechanical behavior.

title: A Numerical Analysis of a NACA 0015 Airfoil with a Dimple on Different Locations
description: This thesis investigates how adding a small indentation, like a golf ball dimple, to different spots on a specific airplane wing shape (NACA 0015 airfoil) affects its performance. Using computer simulations (numerical analysis and computational fluid dynamics), the research aims to understand how these dimples change the airflow and reduce drag, potentially making the wing more efficient. It will explore various dimple positions to find out which location might offer the best aerodynamic improvements. Essentially, it's about making a standard wing better by strategically adding a tiny divot, all analyzed through powerful computer models.

title: Aerodynamics of NACA Series using Constant-Strength Vortex Panel Methods
description: This thesis likely explores how air moves around specific wing shapes, known as NACA series airfoils. It focuses on using a computational technique called "constant-strength vortex panel methods" to simulate and understand this airflow. Essentially, the research will break down the wing's surface into small sections and represent the air's influence using simplified "vortices" of consistent strength. By doing so, it aims to predict aerodynamic forces like lift and drag, offering a practical and numerically efficient way to analyze the performance of these common airfoil designs in various flight conditions. This approach falls under the umbrella of computational fluid dynamics, providing insights without needing physical wind tunnel experiments.

title: Study of a Cathodic Protection System using Mg as a Sacrificial Anode
description: This thesis investigates the effectiveness of using magnesium (Mg) as a sacrificial anode in cathodic protection (CP) systems. It will delve into understanding how Mg prevents corrosion by preferentially corroding itself, thereby protecting a target metal structure. The study will likely involve various materials science techniques to characterize the Mg anode and the protected material, assessing the CP system's performance under different conditions. Ultimately, the research aims to optimize the design and application of Mg-based cathodic protection systems for improved corrosion prevention.
