title: Theoretical and Experimental Study for Inclusion Control in Metal Casting
description: This thesis investigates methods to prevent unwanted non-metallic particles, called inclusions, from forming or becoming entrapped during the metal casting process. It combines theoretical models to understand inclusion behavior with practical experiments to test control strategies. The research aims to develop innovative techniques to minimize these defects, which can significantly weaken the final cast metal product. By optimizing the casting parameters and potentially introducing new technologies, the study seeks to enhance the quality and reliability of manufactured metal components. Ultimately, this work contributes to cleaner metals and improved performance in various engineering applications.

title: Advanced Prevention and Remedy Strategies to Mitigate Fire Hazards
description: This thesis investigates innovative approaches to drastically reduce the risks and damage caused by fires. It delves into understanding the fundamental processes of **combustion** to develop more effective prevention methods. The research will explore how advanced **sensors** can be integrated with **IoT** (Internet of Things) technology to create intelligent, real-time fire detection and early warning systems. Furthermore, it will examine the application of sophisticated **control systems** and **Machine Learning** algorithms to predict fire behavior, optimize resource allocation, and enable autonomous or semi-autonomous fire suppression strategies, ultimately aiming for a proactive and adaptive fire safety paradigm.

title: Design and Simulation of an Automatic TMT BAR Bundle Bending Machine
description: This thesis focuses on developing a machine capable of automatically bending bundles of TMT (Thermo Mechanically Treated) bars, commonly used in construction. It will likely cover the mechanical design of the machine, including its various components and how they interact to achieve the bending process. Key aspects will involve integrating automation principles to reduce manual labor, designing control systems to ensure precise and consistent bending, and utilizing simulation tools to optimize the machine's performance and identify potential issues before physical prototyping. The research will contribute to improving efficiency and safety in manufacturing processes for the construction industry.

title: Study of Temperature Cycling of Rechargeable Lithium-Ion Batteries
description: This thesis investigates how repeatedly heating and cooling rechargeable lithium-ion batteries affects their performance and lifespan. It will likely delve into the internal material changes and stress mechanisms caused by these temperature fluctuations. Researchers might analyze how temperature cycling influences the battery's ability to hold charge, its overall efficiency, and its susceptibility to degradation. The study will likely combine principles of energy storage, heat transfer, and materials science to understand the underlying physical and chemical processes. Furthermore, it might explore the mechanical consequences, such as expansion and contraction, that lead to cracking or delamination within the battery components. Ultimately, the research aims to provide insights into improving the durability and safety of lithium-ion batteries under varying thermal conditions.

title: Noise Emission Reduction of a Jet Engine by Double Cylindrical Perforated Liners in a Combustion Chamber
description: This thesis explores the reduction of noise emitted by jet engines, a significant environmental concern. It specifically investigates the use of a novel acoustic liner system, comprising double cylindrical perforated layers, placed within the combustion chamber. The research aims to understand how these specialized liners can absorb or redirect sound waves generated during the combustion process, preventing them from escaping as loud jet noise. Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) will likely be a key tool used to model and simulate the complex airflow and acoustic interactions within the engine and the proposed liner design. Ultimately, the goal is to develop a more effective method for pollution control by mitigating noise, contributing to quieter aircraft and improved public health near airports.

title: Development of a GSM-Based Low-Cost Weather Monitoring Device for Assisting Agriculture in Bangladesh
description: This thesis aims to develop an affordable weather monitoring device specifically for farmers in Bangladesh. It will use readily available GSM technology to send real-time weather data, such as temperature and humidity, directly to their phones. The project will involve designing the physical device, integrating various environmental sensors, and automating the data collection and transmission process. By providing timely and localized weather information, this system can help farmers make better decisions about irrigation, planting, and harvesting, ultimately improving agricultural productivity. The focus is on creating a practical and cost-effective solution that is accessible to a wide range of farmers in the region.

title: Stress Analysis of a Gearless Power Transmission System with Four and Six Elbow Pins
description: This thesis investigates the structural integrity and performance of a unique power transmission system that operates without traditional gears. Specifically, it focuses on analyzing the stress distribution within this "gearless" system, which utilizes a mechanism incorporating either four or six "elbow pins" to transfer power. The research aims to understand how these different pin configurations affect the system's overall strength and reliability under various operating conditions. Through simulation and potentially experimental methods, the study will identify critical stress points and evaluate the mechanical properties of the components. Ultimately, this work contributes to the design and optimization of more robust and efficient gearless power transmission solutions.

title: Numerical Investigation of Heat Transfer Enhancement through a Tube Fitted with an Alternate-Axis Dimpled Twisted Tape Insert
description: This thesis explores how to make heat transfer more efficient within a tube, a common component in many industrial applications. The research focuses on a specific internal device: an "alternate-axis dimpled twisted tape insert." Using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) and numerical analysis, the study will investigate how this uniquely shaped insert enhances heat transfer by altering fluid flow patterns inside the tube. The goal is to understand the complex interplay between fluid mechanics and heat transfer, ultimately aiming to design more effective and compact heat exchangers. The findings could lead to significant improvements in various heat transfer systems.

title: Design and Fabrication of an Improved Box-Type Solar Cooker
description: This thesis focuses on developing a better version of the common box-type solar cooker. It likely involves the mechanical design of a new or modified cooker, aiming to improve its efficiency in converting sunlight into heat for cooking. The research will probably delve into the fabrication process, detailing how the improved design is built. Key aspects will include understanding heat transfer principles to optimize how the cooker absorbs and retains solar energy, ultimately contributing to the field of renewable energy by making solar cooking more effective and accessible.

title: Fabrication of TiO2 and Graphite Reinforced Aluminum Metal Matrix Composites by Stir Casting Techniques
description: This thesis investigates the creation of new, stronger aluminum materials by adding tiny particles of titanium dioxide (TiO2) and graphite. It focuses on using a method called "stir casting," where these particles are mixed into molten aluminum. The research aims to understand how well these added materials improve properties like strength and wear resistance, essentially making a better, more durable aluminum. This work is important for developing advanced materials for various industrial applications.

title: Biodiesel Production with Characterization and Performance Test of a CI Engine Using Non-Edible Grape Seed Oil
description: This thesis explores the feasibility of producing biodiesel from non-edible grape seed oil. It will likely cover the chemical processes involved in converting the oil into a fuel, followed by a detailed characterization of the resulting biodiesel to assess its properties and quality. A significant portion of the work will involve testing this biodiesel in a Compression Ignition (CI) engine, typically a diesel engine, to evaluate its performance, efficiency, and emissions compared to conventional diesel. title: Computational Simulation of B737D Supercritical Wing with and without Winglet at Cruising Angle

title: Design and Fabrication of a go-kart: chassis construction

title: Heat transfer enhancement and performance analysis between alternate axis flat baffles turbulator and perforated baffles turbulator
description: This thesis explores the effectiveness of different internal structures, called turbulators, in improving heat transfer within systems like heat exchangers. The research will likely use computational fluid dynamics (CFD) to simulate how these turbulators create turbulence and mix fluids, thereby enhancing heat exchange. The goal is to identify which design offers superior performance in terms of maximizing heat transfer while minimizing pressure drop. Ultimately, this work aims to contribute to the design of more efficient and compact heat transfer devices.

title: Experimental analysis of heat transfer enhancement in a circular tube using perforated triangular wavy tape insert
description: This thesis explores the impact of a unique internal design on improving heat transfer within a circular pipe, commonly found in heat exchangers. The research will involve conducting experiments to observe these effects directly. By understanding how this specific tape design enhances heat transfer, the study aims to contribute to the optimization of heat exchanger performance. This could lead to more compact, efficient, and cost-effective heat exchange systems in various engineering applications. title: Heat transfer enhancement with the combination of circular-cut disc twisted tape insert and TiO2/water nanofluid
description: This thesis explores the impact of innovative techniques on improving heat transfer efficiency in systems like heat exchangers. The research likely combines experimental methods with computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations to understand how these elements interact to boost heat transfer, aiming to develop more compact and efficient thermal systems. title: Synthesis and heat transfer enhancement characteristics of TiO2 nanofluids

The core idea is to investigate if these nanofluids can make cooling systems, or any system requiring efficient heat removal, work better. title: Experimental study on performance of heat transfer of a perforated twisted tape insert fitted with conical ring

The research will experimentally investigate how these features, when combined, affect the "performance of heat transfer," meaning how well heat moves from one place to another. This study aims to improve the effectiveness of cooling or heating processes by enhancing fluid movement and heat exchange, ultimately contributing to more efficient heat exchanger designs and potentially better cooling systems.

title: Experimental analysis on enhancement of heat transfer of a plain tube using louvered striped insert combined with nanofluid

title: CFD Analysis of heat transfer enhancement in shell and helical coil heat exchangers using water-based TiO2 nanofluid
